DIV1.P: THE COVNTRIE GIRLE. A Comedie, As it hath beene often Acted with much applause.

LG.L: BEfore I speake, me thinkes, I heare some say,
What can there be, to furnish out a Play,
In such a Home-spun Title?—In a Plaine
Poore Countrey Girle? Such, yeilds no lofty straine;
No sinewie stuffe, extracted from a Myne▪
Of deep, and Abstruse reading; no strong line,
No such a straine, and this poore Title, suite
Like old Pan's Bagpipe, and Apollo's Lute.
What must we looke for then? A desperate wit?
Scoenes, full of veins, where, without a Hit
No man escapes, comes neere it? This indeed
Were to some purpose; and the way to speed.
But this too's from this Title.—None of these?
Alas poore Girle, where's then, thy hope to please?
What can she sing? and, like the Northerne Lasse▪
(That brave blithe Girle) hope to procure a passe?
Or, can she fight?—If so so stout, so bold
A brave Virago, like the Girle, worth Gold.
Or is shee one; that once a Countrey Maide,
Crack'd in the carriage, is come to Trade,
And set up some new Leaguer? Or suppose
Our Girle, a vertuous Copy, and so close
This inquisition of her,—Shee is—what?
Her owne presentment, best can tell you that,
Which be but pleas'd to grace, with love and favour,
You make the poore Girle rich, and Crowne our labour.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Oliver Bellingham, and M. William.

SP.SPEAKER: M. William.
SP.P: BEleeve me Sir, I have told you what your worship may most certainly trust to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliver.
SP.P: May I not speak with her?

LG.L: You know my place.
There's no more hope from the deepe pit of griefe
To raise in her any conceit of love,
Then there's to raise her husband up againe
From the cold bed he sleepes in: from the Grave.
Take this for all: My Lady Sir, has vow'd
To live▪ and die a Widdow.—So I leave you.—
Is't possible, that such a one as shee;
So young, so beautifull; so full of blood;
Such lusty blood, as shee's? for such a losse,
Should lose that youth; that Beauty, that quick blood
In such a cold retirement?—Well, I know not!
But if she have made such a vow, and keepe it!
To finde out such another, and a Phaenix,
Is but an equall labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Save you Sir Oliver; save you, sweet Sir Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: As much to you Sir; kind M. Rash.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: You have bin with the Widdow; this melancholly Lady already. Give you much joy of your faire hopes Sir Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: As much to your self; to your self Sir, kind M. Rash.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P:
Ile hope as much as I can, though you be a Knight; and I but an honest Citizen. A Mercer, is a Merchant, and
will looke for good Ware, for his Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: If he should enter now?—Ile see the issue.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: You know my comming: to speak with your Lady, M. William.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: But shee's not at leasure to heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I hope you doe but jeast.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Beleeve me Sir, in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: But, I'le not take't in earnest.

LG.L: But you must.—Then you'll be Rash indeed Sir.
Though you be a Citizen, you are not free of this Hall,
And therefore must have no admittance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Give you much joy of your faire hopes.
Another?

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Save you Gentlemen: how is't M. Rash?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: As well as we may, M. Plush.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: You have got the start of me, I see that Gentlemen. A Suit, brought me home this morning, made me lye so much the longer: but, my Taylors long Bill, like a Woodcock, as hee is, shall be so much the longer a paying.—You have beene within?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: In our time Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: I meane, this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: But—the Lady meanes no such thing Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: We heard of your Worships new Suit, and would not goe in before it.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: I'le lead the way then.
M. William? good morrow good morrow sweet M. William.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: That sweet, to your sweetest selfe Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: And where's thy Lady?—You see, we come, to come to her.—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: By your favour Sir, you are too hasty.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Why, is not thy Lady up yet?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Why, doe you meane to take her downe Sir?—Buy Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: This Fellow's sawcie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Minds not your Worships new Suit Sir.—But we must be content.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: We may be patient Sir, but not content; for no∣thing contents me, but the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Nor me, but that beautifull Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Who have wee here? Sweet and soft, M. Plush. M. Rash!—I dare be so bold as embrace you too.—But my Noble Sir. My Sir, of a thousand per annum.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Why, I can be a Knight, an I lust Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: An I can be a Knight, an I lust Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Dubd, with the Citie Dagger.—Then Rash, would be rash indeed. You come to see my Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: With all our hearts we would Sir.

LG.L: 'Las good hearts.
Me thinks the Gates should of themselves flye ope,
To such brave men as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: You have the old heart, still Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: The young heart still Sir Oliver;—the mad heart,—the merry heart; the light heart, with the candle of conceit, burning in it, as bright as Lucifer, Hesper, Vesper.

LG.L: You have not bin within? I will make out this paire of Aces,
And then you shall see my Sister.
I perceive by your melancholy looks,
My melancholy, pettish, peevish Sister,
Is not at this time to be spoke withall.
'Tis such a foolish thing;—She knowes not worth,
Nor how to entertain't: suffice it Gentlemen,
I doe;—And shall not goe behind her back
To let her know your merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: Will you Sir?

LG.L: And in a just proportion to that merit,
That Masse of Merit, you shall finde her favour:
So M. Plush, and worthy M. Rash,
I shall desire you leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: You'll remember.

LG.L: Shall I remember (Gentlemen) to eat?
To drink? to sleep?—Then Ile remember you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Then?—When Sir Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P:
When I am asleepe.—Awake, I shall never
mind e'm. For their Worshipe are hardly worth it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Yet in a just proportion, to their merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Yes, that's just nothing:—Hang e'm gloworms, hang e'm.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Here's another rub in our Ally Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: A Tennants sonne o' mine.—And how does my honest Abr'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: The better your good Worship is well Sir. I was to seeke your good Worship, at your Right Worshipfull house Sir: but, missing you there, I rejoyce I have met with you here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter Abr'am, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: In the way of love, as they say: from my father, and my suster; and my tother suster too;—You know who I meane, Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Thy scolding sister. Abr. You are in the right, Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: And how does Margaret, my pretty Tennant?

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: That pretty one, is prettily well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Remember me to her by this.—A Ring.
Within these two or three dayes, at the furthest, I should breath a Gelding; It may be, that wayes, and visit my pret∣ty Tennant.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Long may your Worships Gelding breathe, and your Worshipfull selfe also.
I am in hast Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Take your own time good Abram.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Thank your good Worship Sir Robert.

LG.L: I have done your patience wrong; indeed I have;
But, in the best, that lyes in me to right it Dore stamp.
You shall command me Sir: Now to my Sister.
Now, where's my Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Shee's within Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Come then, let's to her.

LG.L: You must pardon me.
Shee's so retyr'd to solitude; and set
So deep in grief, that till her sighs, and teares,
Will give her leave to give that entertain
That shall become such worthy Visitants,
(Which yet, they will not) tis her strict command
That no man enter.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Rob.
SP.P: Not my self?

LG.L: Your self,
Sir, if you would not swell her grief too big
For her faint breast to carry, give her way.
A little time may change her.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Rob.
SP.P: Tis enough.—You see Sir Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: S Oli.
SP.P: Your Love, Sir Robert.

LG.L: But, as her Gentleman discreetly said,
A little time may change her: We must still
In such a kind humour a womans will.
But, she's thine own, be bold on't.—

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Come, thou mak'st such a Matter, of Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Nothing, doe you call it, Master William? I know not, but I am sure, I feel it something—Tis almost, kicking ripe already.

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Almost, kicking ripe already,—Come, come, thou art, A Chamber-maid still;—And I prethee, whats this, but a work that belongs to the Chamber? Kicking ripe already, This is not the first time, that thou hast been kickt with an urchin. Once, Twice,—this is the third time of kicking.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Well, you wo'not, marry me?

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: And hazard my place, wo my Lady?—and yet, Now I think on't.—I will—

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Marry me?

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: To some of my old acquaintance. There be a hun∣dred in the City, that have swallowed worse bits then thou art. Hist.
SP.STAGE: Enter the Lady Mosely in mourning, veild; the Lady Malory, and an old Gentlewoman.
SP.P: I know, my danger, and shall have a care, according.

LG.L: Beseech you. Let the love you seeme to shew
In these perswasions, be exprest in words,
That better suit with such a robe as this,
And my immutable resolve.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Immutable?—then we perswade, in vain.

LG.L: I am bound to say
You have lost a worthy Gentleman;—My selfe,
A noble Master;—one that was a Man
Worth your best memory: the multitude
Of sighs you have sent after him, worth all
The expence of teares, you have bestowed upon him.
But when we look into his Tombe and there
See him lock'd up in Marble;—in the still,
And sad imagin'd language of the Grave,
We are instructed, Nay, commanded Lady,
To period our vain grievings.
He has told you the naked truth on't.
'Tis but in vaine to grieve;—For, is't not sed
The quick must live byth' quick, and not byth' dead?
He's gone,—Heaven be with him;—He was a Gentleman;
An honest man;—and, which is more;—a proper Gentleman:
But, when Gentility,—Honesty,—and proportion,
Lye in the Grave once, I ha' done with 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Thy tongue's my ceaslesse torment.

LG.L: Let me tell you,
That infinite of love you seeme to have fixt,
Upon the heart of your departed Husband,
Loses no scruple, of the worth it has,
Plac'd on a second Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Mark you that now?

LG.L: Nay, I dare tell you, that in a second Match,
You love him more; more love, more honour him,
Then, in your mourning Widdowhood.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Mark you that now?

LG.L: Ile make it open to you: whilst you keepe
Incompast, with this solitude▪ a Widow,
You seeme, to voyce, to the ill censuring world,
Some imperfection in your selfe; some staine
Makes you unworthy of a second Match:
At lest, unworthy, of a worthy Husband,
And in th' opinion, (which is easily rais'd)
Question your Husbands judgement.—Or, it may be,
The estate he left you Lady;—pulling so
Upon the Name, you strive to dignifie,
Disgrace, defames, and scandall.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Mark you that now?

LG.L: If you so lov'd him living, love him dead,
As I advise you Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: I, I, doe.

LG.L: 'Tis the best Tomb-stone you can lay upon him;
The noblest Monument, you can erect;
And to that Monument, an Epitaph,
Shall make him live for ever.
Law you there now!—Shal make him live for ever!
You are not dumb tro?—are you?
Would thou we't.
Or I had lost my hearing.—I can wish
Nothing more adverse to me, then your tongues:
And therefore, if your visits bring with them
Nothing, but these perswasions.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Keepe away.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Nay, as good speak't as think it.—Here's a coyle for a Husband, I have had for mine owne part,—1.—2.—3.—4. And yet if the fift come up handsomly to me,—I know what I know, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: La, Mal.
SP.P: How five?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Fifteene, an the Destinies so have decreed it.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Madame, there be Suiters below would see you: M. Rash, the Mercer;—one Plush, a humorous Gallant;—and a spick and span new Suiter, a Country Gentleman,—one, M. Gregory Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Spruce M. Rash I know.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: And I M. Plush, a notable humorous Coxcomb. But what's that Gregory?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Unknowne to me: but beleeve me, together, They make up, a delicate motion.—Is your Ladiship pleas'd to see 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Present your Motion some-where else, our griefes give way to no such lightnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Very good.—I'le tell e'm what you say:

LG.L: Pray stay a little.
I know these Suiters are but empty things;
Not worth one serious entertaine; yet Sister,
I wo'd not have you beat e'm back, at dore:
Pray let e'm enter; Let e'm looke upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Still your desire's, my anguish.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Come, come, pray.—You are so melancholly.

SP.SPEAKER: La Mal.
SP.P: Why, their mirth—will be a means to cure you.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Kill me rather.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Goe, prethee bid e'm come.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Bid e'm be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Nay, then, y'are too too cruell.—Prethee stay.

LG.L: Nay, an you know no other merriment,
Then what you raise from my vexation, take it;
I will not hinder your desires; pray take it.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: You will not leave us, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Leave this roome.

LG.L: And goe mew your selfe up in your Chamber?
An you will needs:—Let me entreat one favour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mos.
SP.P: Well, what is't?

LG.L: That, in your absence you'd be pleas'd to let
Your wayting Gentlewoman, Mistris Barbary,
Appeare in your apparrell: Tis but slipping off
This upper garment; and this mourning Veile,
And shees my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: How?—My Bab, my Lady!

LG.L: It will be sport to us; and to your selfe
A rare advantage Sister: for this trick
Keepes all your foolish Suiters at that distance,
Their trouble shall ne're touch you.—Will you?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Will you?

LG.L: Though pleasure, be no pleasure to this bosome,
Since you propose th'acquittance of that trouble,
Your desire's granted.
But be speedie then
With your directions for her carriage in it, Exit L. Mosly.
And we shall fit 'em neatly.—Call e'm in.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Did you ever see such a self-will'd thing as this is?—a widdow these two moneths, and yet not heare of a Suiter.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter M. William, Rash, Plush, and Gregory.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: The Gentlemen, an't please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Yes indeed, an't please you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Master Rash.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Your servant, good deed law, Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mal.
SP.P: Master Plush.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: My name is Plush; Master my Title, and Sir, a Title, that may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: And my name is Gregory—

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Fop: thy sound is out o' season.—But where's the Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I, where's the Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Wee would see the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: I hope she has done mourning now,—has she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Why, dos the Lady mourne?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Indeed shee dos.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Tis a delicate thing to mourne.—Well, an my Fa∣ther wou'd but dye once!
Would we could see this Lady.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Barbara, like her Lady, arm'd in by M. William.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: You have your wish already.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Beautious Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Most beautious Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Most beautifull Lady, that may be: for yet, I see no such matter.

LG.L: Thine eyes are veyl▪d with ignorance, or else,
Through this thin veile, thou might'st, as we,—behold
Matter of admiration!—You'll vouchsafe;—
Not yet.
Alas:—upon their Captive heart,
My sorrowes yet have set too strong a Guard
For such delights to enter.
I could wish▪
That Conquerour of thy heart, and all his Guard
Were visible, that I might challenge them.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: I marry sir; that wee a challenge indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Me thinks I could—doe—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: What, doe you think you could doe Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: O—my most delicate Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Doe,—his—most delicate Lady.—A ter∣rible doe, indeed law.

LG.L: Well Lady; if this be the man shall have you,
You shall have a man, I can tell you.
If I be the man that shall have her,
Shee shall have a man, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: O Gent.
SP.P: But, hee's a fighting man.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: A fighting man?—Let him play at the ancient wea∣pon, an he were a Fencing man, I'll have a Bout with him.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: The ancient weapon?—What weapon's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Why this?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: As wise, as valiant! 'tis the ancientst weapon in∣deed Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: And why not this?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I am better acquainted with this.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Well, wee shall meet?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: And meet agen:—Tell me of fighting Lady!

LG.L: I see you are valiant Sir;—and you are happy
In having so much valour as you see
Attend your beauty.
I must confesse them, worthy Gentlemen;
But they must pardon me:—the worth I ha' lost,
With my dead husband, is so full, and fresh,
Upon my understanding, that all else
Have et but homely entertaine:—And yet,
Y'are welcom Gentlemen.—

SP.SPEAKER: All 3.
SP.P: For that, we thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: We must hope still.

LG.L: Well, an my Father would but dye once!
I live in hope too Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: You see their valour Sir:—and what's your wea∣pon?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I am no man of the sword;—I have no weapon.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: How Sir?—No weapon!—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P:
What should
you do in Cupids fencing Schoole, And have no weapon?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: There was a time,—I could have crost a eudgell.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: And that you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Good sooth sometimes I can tell you:—yet, if any man strike me, I have a weapon too Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: The coldest flint, has fire I see: What weapon?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: One, that is indeed,—All weapons.—Long-Sword; Sword and Dagger;—Sword and Buck∣ler; Single Rapier, Rapier and Dagger; Case o' Rapiers; Halbert, Halfe-Pike; Quarter-Staffe; Short-Sword and Gauntlet; and that terrible Fly-flap, the Fauchion.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: All these in on?—

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Or one that's worth all these;—and that,—in a word, is the Law Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: A terrible weapon indeed Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash,
SP.P: There, let mee firk 'em, and jerk 'em: There, Let mee stand upon Tearmes;—There, Let me play the Ma∣ster, and M. Atturny, my Vsher, and then,—with all the weapons in that School, have at 'em.

DIV2.STAGE: En. Sir Rob. and Sir Oli.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: This goes beyond your Rapier; or your ancient weapon, the Fist.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mal.
SP.P: Body o' me, my husband, and Sir Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: What's to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mal.
SP.P: Doe, as thou hast done Wench.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Play the Lady, a little longer.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mal.
SP.P: Handsomly Bab, and I'le promise thee, it shall cost me a Chamble Pettycoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: I'll do't as well as I can then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Come, come, we will speake, and speed too, my Knight, of a thousand per annum where's this mourning La∣dy?—What, my Madona?—and my Lady Littleworth. Hoyday? This Covy of Coxcombs too!

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob
SP.P: One.—

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Kind Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Two.—

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Worthy Sir Robert.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Three, yet never a wise word amongst 'em.—What, still in Dubs, and dolors?—An ye were as heavy as Lead, 'twas but a light trick of you to deny Accesse to such a brave man as this is, and allow't to such Mimicks as these are.—Death, could kick e'm out o' the roome. And you, though you bee my wives sister, for lodging such basenesse within you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Why, you are not out of your wits?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: You have no wit to be out of. Gentlemen, you are all—Hobbyhorses. An it please you, to leave the house now; and come agen,—when you are sent for,—you shal be—heartily glad, to be welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: You see his humour Gentlemen; pray leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: There's no resisting of him; for he has Rapier, fist, the law, and all, for any man, that shall thwart him.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Why, but I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mal.
SP.P: Not one word more, an you love me.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Off, ere the flame grow higher.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Come, take my counsell, and forget him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Still looking downward, to your husbands grave?

LG.L: To those that weare so sad a suit as this,
The Grave's the glasse they use to deck e'm by.
Pray give me leave.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mal.
SP.P: Shee dos it to a haire.

LG.L: Prethee look up a little;—I can shew thee
A Glasse, shall shew thee better things;—a Glasse,
That shall reflect, no such affrighting shadowes—
Nor shadowes (beautious Lady) but the same
True, and essentiall comforts.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Excellent, mourning Lady.

LG.L: The Nuptiall knot, binds loving Paires together,
Only for terme of life, has no extent
O're the divorce of Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Pray, pray no more.

LG.L: That onely binds the living to the living,
And not the living to the dead.
That flesh that has a soul within it, the indow∣ments,
And excellencies, bounteous Heaven bestowes,
To that, has nothing but the frightfull shape,
And key-cold figure of a man.
Yet this,
While thus, you dote upon your husbands dust,
You doe sweet Lady; and this beauty bind
To stenches, and corruption; so imposing
Upon your selfe Mezentius cruelty.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: You have my resolution; so, pray leave me.

LG.L: An you be buried in your Husbands grave,
I see my suit must dye too.
Yes, and let it
For ever, Let it die to her, and live
To one that better shall deserve it: come,
I'le bring thee, though shee be mine owne Madona's Sister,
My Knight, of a thousand per annum, to her betters:—one that is younger, fairer, richer, and it may be,—Honester too Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mal.
SP.P: How Sir Robert? Honester.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Honester?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: An shee prostrate her selfe to a set o' Morris∣dancers;—and neglect such a Caesar as this is.—Come Sir Oliver, come, let's away.

LG.L: Nay, but heark you, heark you Sir Robert; and worthy Sir Oliver; that you may see this Lady,
Is not the woman that you take her for;
Looke, doe you know this Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: How, Mistris Bab?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: My Ladies Chambermaid!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: A trick o' mirth they put upon these Coxcombs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Were you my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: So, your Lady would have it, Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Why, god-a-mercie faith.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: There's all the comfort they are like to have.

LG.L: This cloud's like Iuno; the poore shadow Sir.
The substance, wee'll court for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: My Lady Bab.—How like you this Sir Oliver?

LG.L: This change, has put some life into me Sir.
And I must tell you, betterd my opinion
Both of the Ladies wisedome, and her goodnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: But heark you wife, may we not see my Sister?

LG.L: aith, yet her temper is not as Wee'd have it:
But we shall win her by degrees, and turne
Her melancholy to a sprightly humour.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: A day, or two dayes passage.

LG.L: Come Sir Oliver.
Meane time wee'll see what mirth my house can yield
To entertaine you with.—A ha, my Girle!
Why such a Wench is worth her weight in Pearle.
Well, thou hast played my Lady, like a Lady.
I have a trick from this conceit, to doe,
Shall make us sport, and help thy swelling too.

DIV2.HEAD: Act. 2.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter old Thrashard, and Margaret his daughter, neatly drest.

SP.SPEAKER: Margaret.
SP.P: Sir, I have spoke my danger.

LG.L: A dangerous case beleeve me.
And yet, me thinks, there's no great danger neither.
For, say a man offer to blowe thee up with Love-powder,
If his traine lie so open, you may see it, you have the wit I hope to shun it;—h'an't you.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: I have done hitherto.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: And doest thou feare,—thou shalt hold out no longer?

LG.L: Sir, I doe not.
For, all the pollicies, and power he has,
Can ne're prevaile to conquest.—No, tho feare
Be to our Sex a common attribute;
In such a fight as this, my resolution
Has that Heroick temper, I dare meet
My death, e're my dishonour:—my dishonour!
For vertue's vertue, in what breast soere,
And her great splendour, equall.
Splend?—Heyday!
But to the point, what is he?—Do I know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, if you know Sir Robert Malory, Your Landlord Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: How Sir Robert?

LG.L: He.—Sometimes,—(tho clouded in a course disguise)
He layes temptations to mine eare himselfe:
Sometimes by deputy; sometimes by Letters;
And sometimes by rich gifts.—As if that Jemme
(Once gone) can never be bought back againe,
Were to be fold so basely.—Here's my sore,
Assist me in the remedie.
Sir Robert!
He ayme against thy chastity? Alas.
Has he bestowed upon thine Infancie,
That care, and cost, that he has done?—Maintain'd thee
Among his owne?—Fed thee among his owne?
Apparrel'd thee, as he has cloth'd his owne?
In the same Schoole, in the same qualities,
Had thee instructed with his owne?—Has he
So beautified thy mind?—So grac'd thy body!
So many yeares in his owne house!—And now—
(So close his favours follow thee)—does he
Maintaine thee here?—Here in this homely Roofe,
A starre to that poore glimmering candle light,
My poverty could afford thee!—And for this,
Is this the best you can returne him?
No—Father, for these should I forget to pay,
The most obsequious duties I can tender,
'Twere just in heaven I should forget my selfe.
Had this beene spoke of any other man.
I might have lent an eare to't:—but, Sir Robert!
Noble Sir Robert!—that brave man, Sir Robert!
Our bountious Benefactor!—Say he have
Scatter'd some words ith' way of merriment,
Some pleasant, idle,—wanton,—what d' yee call't?
Sprinkled a little Bawdry in his speech?
(As Courtiers may, and ne'r be question'd for it)
That cuts not off a May denhead.—Nay, perchance
The merriment, that you in erpret lust,
Was his meere love to vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Vertue!

LG.L: Yes.—Tis my conceit, that all his talk,—his
Letters, and all the gifts he sent thee, were imployed,
' way of triall:—Not to make thee naught;
But, so to sound thy goodnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sound my goodnesse!

LG.L: Not to o'recome thy chastity; but to try
If any other should assaile the Fort,
How stoutly thoud'st maintaine it.
Think you so?
I'le think so too then Father:—Let him try me.
But jest, or earnest, he shal ne'r come nye me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: Why, this is fine, you have the golden time on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: What golden time?—You'll still be scolding.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: Scolding!—Mary come up Mistris Jinnie-innie; We cannot speak to you, but we scold.—Well, I say little.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: Nothing at all were better.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: But I'll say something; Has a woman a tongue to say nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Prethee be patient Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: Yes I waun't you. I must wash, and scowre; And Brew, and Bake, and doe this thing,—and doe that thing; and doe every thing; while such a beautifull Blowse as you are, must sit still o' your taile, and doe nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: Why, doest thou not see her at her work?

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: At wok!—A geate peyce o work, a deed law!—Prick, prick, prick.—As if shee had nothing in the world to mind—but Prick, Prick, Prick.—But 'tis no matter,—tis but my hard fortune; I am a foole indeed, and so you make me.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: What, what, a shower after this peale of thunder?—Na, doe not crie good Gillian.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: O, Father, Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: Now Boy, what newes with you now?

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: Brave newes Father,—News of the brave Sir Ro∣bert

LG.L: Pursue me still?—Good Father give me leave,
While hee's come in, and gone agen.—

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: What leave?

LG.L: To absnt my selfe;—but in some neighbours house:
I have a trick to passe him—You may tell him,
I'm gone to London.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: When I have told him already, you are here in the Parlor a sewing.

LG.L: Come, y'are a Baggage; y'ar a foolish Baggage,
To injure with such frivolous suspiions,
A Gentleman of his repute, and goodnesse!
Come, let me heare no more on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: Sister Gillian,—I have the rarest newes for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: For me▪tis wel;▪ And what news have you got for me Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: Skipping news, lipping news, tripping news.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: How, Dancing brother Abr'am?—Dancing!

LG.L: Prancing, advancing, dancing!
Nay, 'tis a Match;—a Match upon a Wager.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: A Match.—Who be they?

LG.L: Why, all the Maids of our Town Edmonton,
And all the mad Wenches of Waltam.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: A Match, and leave me out?—When, when is't Brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Mary, e'n this morning;—they are now going to't, helter skelter.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: And leave me out? —Where brother Abram? where?

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: Why there, Sister Gillian; there.—At our owne dore almost: O the Greene there, close by the May-pole. Heark, you may heare them hither.

LG.L: Ta la la la leero, ta la, la leero—&c.
An I be not one.—

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Thou't never be two, I think;—For on my con∣science, there is no man that knowes her, has valour enough, to come neere her▪

LG.L: Why, well said Girle, keepe but that resolution, Enter Sir Robert Malry.
And let his purposes, be what they can,
They cannot hurt thee.—Look, hee's come already.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Good morrow Tennant;—good morrow beautiful Tennant.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: As much to my worthy Landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: As much to my worthy Landlord.

LG.L: My Tennant Abra'm!—God-a-mercy good
Tennant Abra'm.
I want your welcome faire one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir, you are welcome.

LG.L: Had this bi spoke, with smiles upon thy cheek,
I durst have sworne the Syllables had beene
The Language of thy heart; thy heart, sweet Peggy.
What, still so adverse to my pleasure?—Tennant—
And my young Tennant;—shall I crave the Roome?
I have something to deliver from my Lady,
That she would have a secret to the Eare
Of any, But faire Margaret.
The Roome?
Our poverty possesses nothing Sir,
But what is yours; you may command it.—Come.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: I smell my Landlord; but,—no words but mum.

LG.L: Still, still this cloud upon thy brow sweet Peg?
You know my minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And you know mine Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: I meane, I love thee, my sweet Peggy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Doe you?—Not halfe so well as I love you.

LG.L: Love me!
Then there's some hope agen.—Why, god-a-mercy,
Let's see how handsomly thou't give thy body
To my embraces Girle.—How, fly e'm Peg?
Not kisse me neither?—such a thing deni'd,
How canst thou say thou lovest me?
Yes Sir Robert:
I love you in your Name: your Reputation;
The dignity you carry in your yeares;
The goodnesse should goe with e'm;—In your Lady;
I love you Sir, ith' faire Benevolence
You owe her vertues.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Hoyday;—Love me qha!—Nay, come, come.

LG.L: I love you in your vowes.
Those Nuptiall vowes, that whilst you live should live
Unstain'd between you:—In a word Sir Robert,
I love you in that purity,—that shall,
When death shall threaten your last minute to you,
Make you look boldly on him; smile upon him;
And in conclusion, seale you, one of those,
That, from this veyle of trouble, he conveyes
To th' purity of Angels:—Thus, I love you.
This is not that I look for: heark you Margaret;
Your Father is my Tennant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir, he is.

LG.L: Nay, since you vrge it, let me tell you Minion,
He's not my Tennant, neither; but my Beadsman.
And like an humble Beadsman, in his Prayers
Remembers all your Charity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: He does:—But you forget it faire one.

LG.L: Then let heaven,
Whence we Petition, the Reward it merits,
Forget me too.
Is't not forgetfulnesse
When all the love,—the tender cares, and cost,
That from thy Infancie, to this Ripe groweth,
I have bestowed upon you, cannot gaine me
Such a request as this is!
This? Alas.
Your greatest gaine's in losing.—Nay, I'le tell you,
The love, the care,—that cost, that Noble breeding,
That seemes to you a winning Argument,
Is my best Argument against you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: How?

LG.L: Why Sir, the Education;—that faire breeding
You have bestowed upon my poverty,
Has made me what I am:—So copiously
Furnish'd my soule, with all that best adornes her,
That whatsoere's in opposition to't,
Has no admittance to her;—Neere her;—No,—
But,—most deservedly, doe rank themselves
With things, that most displease her.—Such a thing,—is—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: What?—My Love?

LG.L: No, but your lust Sir Robert.—I am bold,
But I can kneele to beg your mercy for it.
What, she imagines water to my flame,
Is oyle t'encreas't: the more she puts me off,
The more she pulls me to her.—Come, come rise,
Though you be so unkind;—Come, prethee kis me. Kis her▪
Why, God a mercy Peg;—agen, agen;
Why, this is somewhat yet: Wee must not look
At once, to have so great a happinesse
As that we ayme at. We must use degrees.
Lock me, once more, in thy embrace, and busse me,
And then.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What then?

LG.L: For this time Peg I'll leave thee.—
What, leave thee, and leave nothing with thee Wench?
Nay, that were foule play Peggy: there,—Nay, take it.
Indeed you shall.
Indeed, indeed I wonot:
For any service, I can doe you Sir,
Your favour's price sufficient.—No, not yet?
I see, mine eye's a Remora:—I ha't.
How I forget my duty?—Here so long,
And ne'r a Chaire to ease you?—Abra'm,—Brother.
Pray pardon me Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: How, a Chaire?—Kinder, and kinder still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Come, come, a Chaire there for Sir Robert.

LG.L: She pitties your standing Sir Robert.—But I have a Chaire,
Almost at my fingers end.—Look you Sir,
Will it please you. Bum this Cushion?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: How, Bum it ennant?

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Yes, Bum it Landlord:—Looke you Sir, o' this fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Come, you'll be foolish stil.—You know my mind. Goe, bring ▪m in.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: An I bring e'm not in, let Sir Rob. kick me out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Lord, how forgetfull I have beene Sir Robert? But, I beseech your pardon.

LG.L: Pardon thee?
And seal't upon thy lip;—Come prethee sit. Treble within.
Nay, nay, sit by me;—Ne'r a stoole?—Sit here then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Be fairely civill Sir;—Nay, good Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: How now,—what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Musick Sir Robert.

LG.L: Musick?—Rot on their fiddle, and their fiddle strings,
Thou art my Musick.—Hoyday, here's a Morice.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter six Country Wenches, all red Pettycoates, white stitch'd Bodies, in their Smock-sleeves, the Fidler before them, and Gillian, with her Tippet up, in the midst of them dancing▪ Abram with e'm.

LG.L: You see we swet to make your Worship merry.
How doe you like our pastime?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: I like it so well, I could wish you were furder off with't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayds.
SP.P: Have we this for our kindnesse Sir Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: Mary, come up Sir Robert.

LG.L: Nay, there's no talking to e'm.
Come, in the heat, and height, of all her kindnesse!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Shall I entreat you, Leave the Roome?

SP.SPEAKER: Mayds.
SP.P: The Roome!

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: So she sed: but I know shee meanes no such mat∣ter,—onely a trick:
Tell her, you wonnot goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pray leave the Roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayds.
SP.P: We wonnot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Wonnot?

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Peg.
SP.P: Wee were sent for in; and wee wonot goe out a∣gen yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mayd.
SP.P: An your Knighthood were—

SP.SPEAKER: Peg.
SP.P: —A 1000 pounds purchase.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Hoyday, they'l bayt me,—and they wonot I must.

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: Out?—Marry gip there, ne'r a good inch of a thousand.—Fidler, strike.
I strike you else;—and cut your begging bowstrings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: I must be gone I see: these miserably impudent stallions—Do but remember me, as I shall thee;—and—Nothing greeves me,—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: But what Sir Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: That,—we cannot kisse at parting—

SP.SPEAKER: Gil.
SP.P: Come,—wee'll een have the tother out,—and then.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, wee'll no more at this time here's enough.

LG.L: For you:—But 'tis not enough for me then:
You shall command us, shall you?
Nay, be not angry Sister:
'Tis no command, but my entreat:—Good Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Peg.
SP.P: Well, since you entreat me, and seem to know your betters,—you shall have your will, for once.—Fid. lead the way;—and Wenches follow your Leader.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr
SP.P: Leader.—An scolding were fighting, what a Leader wouldst thou be Gillian?—Thoudst bring 'em on, with a pouder. O Father, Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: Ne'r a wise word, for a wager.—Sir Robert's gone I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes Sir, he is.

LG.L: And how do'st find him Girle? I doe not think
The man, that thy suspition seem'd to make him.
You have a good opinion of him Father,
And, I'll not stand to crosse it.
Nay, nay, come;
In plaine termes, tell me▪ how didst find him?—ha?
As good conceal't, and languish, as reveal't,
And find no comfort.
Th'art a pertish thing:
And—I'm afraid, have beene distastfull to him:
I'm halfe afraid on't Girle:—we must be wise;
By's own we fall Wench; by his favours rise.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Oliver Bellingham, and the Lady Mosely.

LG.L: Distilling still, salt water to deface
That Master-peece of Nature?—Can the heart
Thus feast it selfe, upon the Baine of hearts?
For such is griefe sweet Lady.
Good enough▪
To make this flesh as my dead Husbands is,
A banquet to corruption.
Still that Note?
Touch onely that dull string of death?
When life
Would willingly exchange it selfe with Death,
What Musick sweeter?
I must tell you Lady,
I thought the Musick of your Husbands end,
Those heavenly Notes he entertain'd it with,
Taught him by Angels, had instructed you,
To looke upon that Being that he has,
As hee's a glorious Chorister with them!
And not upon that Burden of the flesh
Left in the Grave behind him.—Or at least,
Not so, to looke upon your Husband dead,
As thus, to dye your selfe. For what is't, while
Of Lifes best hopes, you shall your Life deprive,
But what I tell you?—to be dead, alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Sir, as I am, pray leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Only so?—Out-ryvald by the dead.

LG.L: To me hee lives:
And in so vive a figure, every houre's
Presented to me, that I feele no lesse
Command o▪re my ffections in that shape;
Nor lesse Attraction of my duty to it,
Then when he had that hear, gave all those parts,
That now ly uselesse, their peculiar motion.
Nay, so that shape▪s imprest upon my soule,
That he appeares so really mine owne,
As, all the embraces of a second March
Would ick upon me, like the leaprous staines
Of Lust, and base Adultry. In a word▪
That figure his bosome:—And in this
Pray understand the vainenesse of your suit,
And so▪ conclude it.
This command upon it,
It dies, though I dye with it.—Yet thus much Lady,
I have not, in this eagernesse of Suit,
Pusued, what's yours, But you.—The gifts of Fortune;
The state your birth allowed you▪ or th'addition,
By your lost husband, left you; But the indowments
Of your faire soule,—your vertues,—And of those
The amplst Dower, (I cannot slatter here)
Beauty was ever blest withall! These Lady
Have beene the object of my Love.
A Love,
That, could I love, I should ee'n dote upon;
And in a Title, farre beneath your owne,
Prefert, above all Title; though it came
Roabd in the state of Princes.—But—
No more.
I have my answer, and am married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Married!

LG.L: As you are Madam; never to be married:
Be that the witnesse of my Love.
Admir'd!
I should not be a woman, should I not
Love such a Love as this is!
Doe you Lady?
Then, I revoke that Vow, and dare embrace you.
But understand me Sir▪ I love your Love:
And—as your selfe, have pleas'd to speak of me
Those singular Vertues, it is built upon▪
That, I am fixt on; with that estimate,
That, next the memory of my dead husband,
I shall be my best comfort.—Thus I love you;
But, must not marrye.
I ha' done.—Yet Lady
In this;—this purest, Imateriall things
There may be made a contract; and the assurance
Of such a Love, as this is, Interchang'd
And fairelie seald betweene vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Sir, how meane you?

LG.L: Fair'st, you have vowed your widowhood to the grave,
At least, you have so protested: yet because
Our hearts, and purposes, are not our owne;
And, that no Bosome has that Constancie,
But Heav'ns may alter, the resolve it has,
And make it follow, what it fled;—it may.
My Love Petitions, that if ere hereafter,
You find that alteration, in your soule,
And againe Fancie Wedlocke,—I—your servant,
May—for that second hapinesse to heaven,
Stand fair'st in your Election.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Pray no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Give my request an answer:—If you doe.

LG.L: A fruitlesse promise: and suppose it made,
This would but—
What?—I vnderstand you Lady.
It shall not make me bolder, in my suite;
Nor prompt my love, in any treacherous way
To gaine, what it so followes.—No; I know
The man, would basely, compasse such a Ioy,
Like him that fishes with a poyson'd Bayte,
Infects the meat should feed him.—fair'st, I wo'not;
Nor vex you with one syllable; but Live,
Vowed, like your selfe, till such a change shall be
To amorou Language, silent.—Is it graunted?
If my bst thoughts merit but this, expresse it
That satisfaction take.—If ere I Marry
It shall be you; so helpe me heav'n.
To which
I am rapt in this sweete tone.—If ere I know
The sweetes of Hymen, I must find'em here;
So helpe me heav'n!—So, we are maried now:
And in this Ioy I leave you.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter the Lady Malorie, and the old Gentlewoman.

LG.L: What Sir Oliver? going
As we are entring?

SP.SPEAKER: O Gen.
SP.P: Does your Lady, drive you hence with a frowne?

LG.L: My smiles may tell you, here has bin no frowning.
Shee's faire and noble; and in these sweet hopes, Enter Sir Rob. Malorie.
That she has given me, I am pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: O Gen.
SP.P: 'is well.

LG.L: A vengeance of all morrice dauncers▪
I am sure, they h'a mar'd, my dancing: that delicate dance
That I should have had with my tenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: All Ioy be with you Ladies; I must leave you,

LG.L: Here's a ub in your way a while, my brave
Knight, of a 1000. per Annum.
And how do'st find her?—is she comming? ha?
You see my hops set smiles upon my cheeke,
Let them resolve you sir.
I vnderstand you:
Why? god a mercy sister: when's the day?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Nay, question that no farther, we shall talk on't.

SP.SPEAKER: O Gen.
SP.P: When a things done, 'tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: You'd faine be doing to then.

LG.L: Wo'd I not?
Do you think I am all dead flesh?—I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Now Mr. William?—what good tidings now sir?

LG.L: My newes is, worthie sir, that Mullinex
That stout sea Captaine, is return'd from sea:
Is come to London, and that yesterday▪
He was upon th' Exchange.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: George Mullinex?

LG.L: That Gentleman:—and but this morning Lady,
He wa seene at the Phaenix, in fleeet-street.
Body o'me I should have told you so—but, I
Have suh a Memory—!

SP.SPEAKER: . Oli.
SP.P: How 'st?—ha?—you lose colour .

SP.SPEAKER: O Gent.
SP.P: Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal
SP.P: Sister

LG.L: Beshrew the name, and owner of that name
That has disturbed you.—whats that name to you?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Sir, nothing but my trouble.

LG.L: A troublesome Captaine indeed sir,
A suytor once, in her virgin dayes
And Rivall to her husband, Sir Iames Mosely.
But, mis'd the marke he aymed at—he shot saire▪
But Mosely fairer.—upon which, Sir Oliver
He went to sea; where having bin three yeares,
And now Returning, hearing, (as it seemes)
That she's a widow, hee'd renew his suite,
Give her a broad-side sir, and boord her! Nay
Yave a hot Ryvall, I can tell you that:
One that will Quarrel;—fight—and—by my fay—
I'm halfe afraid of danger.
If he be not,
All valour, and no judgement, I feare none;
And yet, that heate, that has not judgement with it,
Cannot be counted valour, but a rash
Unknowing wilnesse,—which I wo'not thinke
Him guilty of;—But, whatsoe'r he be,
I'll be, but what becomes me.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: Leave the Roome.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Good truth now, but you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Leave the Roome?—What feare you Lady?

LG.L: I have cause enough,
For hee'll but trouble me with that, heaven knowes
I have no mind to heare of.
If he have
No power upon you Lady by some promise,
Formerly past betweene you—
I had never,
That unprepar'dnesse in me, to doe that
In cause of such a Consequence as this,
And breake it sir.
Such Beauty, and untruth
Were ne're comoanions: 'tis beleev'd.
Come, come,
It may be, some new Beautie has him now:
Some Forraigne Mistris.
Or, it may be sister,
This time of service in the warres, had made him
Onely in love, with fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mose.
SP.P: More vexation?

LG.L: This Mountaine, bring forth a Mouse▪
Have we talk'd all this while of a Captaine,
And now, must be troubled, with Coxcombs?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: The gods, protect you Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: O Gen.
SP.P: Thanke you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: I spoake to that sweet Beauty.

LG.L: But I must speake to you sir; for you see she has other imployment,
Pray, stand aside a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: If I must—I shall attend her leasure.

SP.SPEAKER: O Gen.
SP.P: You must attend her too sir:—doe you not see, shee's busie?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I would not interrupt her.

LG.L: I would not interrupt her?—Is that the resolution of a Lover?
Let me come to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: But, you shall not sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Why? if I shall not sir,—I wo'not sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Is that the resolution of a Lover?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Capt. Mul∣lyneux rushing in by Mr. William and others.

LG.L: A man can do, no more then a can do,
But, an my father would but dye once!
Make nyce to me of entrance?
Where's the Widow?
For so I heare shee's now: what mourning still?
I'm a bold gamester:—Save you all at once.
All suiters Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Yes indeed sir; we are all suitors.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Y'are a little too rash in that sir; I am none.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: And, what, are you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Why sir,—I am,—a Citizen, and a Mercer.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: A Citizen, and a Mercer,—Cheapside?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: No Captain;—but he's perfect in his Pater noster.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: One of that row?—I know't sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Not very farre from it:—In Creed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Does he beleeve? that's seldome found in a Broker.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: How sir,—a Broker?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: I know you by this wheele.—you have a great many Bags, and a great many buildings to sir.—But, dare you for all that, presume in the way of Matrimonie, to looke so high as a Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash
SP.P: He that can purchase a Lordship—

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Thinks, he may purchase a Ladiship:—you my Rivall? Can you fight sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: It may be I, it may be no sir.

LG.L: Then I'le try, whether you can or no sir. Kicks him and thrust him out.
Not a word, as you love your Coxcomb.
Nay, let him alone; let him alone, I beseech you,
For hitherto he has done but Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Are you a Suiter too sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Too sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Y'are an Asse sir:—Can you fight?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Fight? in a Ladyes chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Why, where would you fight sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Why, the truth on't is;—I would—fight,—no where.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Why, I thought as much;—and therefore,—I will kick you—any where; good master outside of a Gentle∣man; follow your valiant Leader.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gen.
SP.P: You will not kill him, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Ha' you so much Tongue, and nev'r a good Tooth, Madam Fumble!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gen.
SP.P: Fumble, fumble!—y'are a most—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Peace, an you love your old Carkasse,—peace.

SP.SPEAKER: La Mose.
SP.P: You bind me to a patience—

LG.L: Nay, good Sister:—He does you a great deale a right,
And saves me a great deale of labour.
For I should have don't, if he had not.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: One post support another?—What are you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Why,—I am—a Gentleman.—

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Will your Armes beare you out in the Title?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: My Legs, shall beare me out sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Then—you wo'not be beat out—as they were?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: —Beat, I should be very loath to be beaten?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: —good truth, I thinke you would sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Doe I looke like one that would be beaten?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: An you stay, you must.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Why therefore,—I meane,—to be gone sir.—But—If my father,—would but dye once.—

LG.L: You see his rudenesse:—to prevent the danger,
It threatens, and may execute,—pray leave us.
I will not adde to his too prodigall heate.
Nor be so cold to feare it.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: 'Tis my Love—

LG.L: And mine to tarry,—not offending you
I'th' humble contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Are these your suiters Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: A little in jeast;—but you ha' paid 'em in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gen.
SP.P: I did but speake, in the way of compassion & pit∣ty,—and your Lordship cal'd me,—Madam fumble, fumble, fumble ▪
Did I ever fumble wo'you sir?

LG.L: Be wise in being silent,
I heare you have lost a Husbnd:—How is't Widow?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: You'l quarrell with her too, will you?

LG.L: You are so nyce:
I cannot Complement, kisse your white hand,
And fleare upon ou.—I can kisse thy lip.
Hug thee, and tell thee, I must ly with thee.
There may be those of your acquaintance Captain,
To whom this language would be musique:—But
To let you know how ill't appeares to me,
I'll change my roome sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: But you shall not Madam.

LG.L: You lay too rude a violence, upon
The tendernesse of Ladyes.
Doe I so sir?
I thanke your kind remembrance,—you the man?
This Ladyes only man sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: My desire's,—you would not be uncivill.

LG.L: What so ere
My will produces, I shall justifie.
That power maintaines offence, is weaknesse sir,
And has no tast of breeding, or of manhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: I'le make you tast of something.

LG.L: But you sha'not Enter Mr. William, & Cutt.
Have we no servants neere us?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Save him, help.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Gent.
SP.P: O, y'are a wicked Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cutt.
SP.P: What? naked weapons in a Ladyes chamber?

LG.L: Take her in,—poore Lady, Exit La. Mosley.
How she's frighted?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugh.
SP.P: My Noble Knight and Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: We haue done sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: An you ha' done, there's nothing to doe;—If no∣thing to do,—the lesse to care for;—the lesse to care for,—the ounder we sleepe:—and asleepe, we thinke no body hurt sir.—And so—having done, I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You have the advantage of me.

LG.L: I must tell you,
This rudenesse, better would become the field
Then such a place as this.
That you may know,
I know as much, as you instruct me to,
Meet me to morrow.—You conceive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Where?

LG.L: Where?—as your selfe have most discreetly said,
My valour would shew better:—in the field sir.
I understand you;—understand withall,
A life, a thing too pretious, to be put
On such a desperate hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Desperate hazard?

LG.L: You have not moved me to that heat, shal give you
One mis-beseeming syllable:—much lesse
Provoke, to what you urge.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You wo'not?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: As good h'a said you dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Dare not?—What?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Not be a man.

LG.L: You better might ha' sed
I dare not, dare my Maker;—and un-make
My selfe, or you rash Captaine,—'t may be both;
'Tis to be thought on, if we meet.
It is
Pretty Apologie; All Cowards, use it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: How, Cowards?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Coward.

LG.L: How his lunacie
Has shot it selfe into my Blood?—a Coward!
Proclaime me, what you call me, if I be

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You'll meet me then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Where thou, or I.

LG.L: Nay,—if you break so violently out Here Sir Robert Malory and his Lady returne. Embraces betweene them.
I shall suspect, 't is to prevent our meeting:
For Manhood covers such intents as these
Under a friendly seeming:—thus.—

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: I marry Gentlemen, I like this close.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Beleeve me, I was jealous of worse matters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro
SP.P: And I, ne'r trust me else.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Of what, Sir Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: I thought you had made some Quarrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Quarrell? no—this is no quarrelling Posture.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Nay, nay, Gentlemen; so fight and spare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: I'll so fight and spare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You know the place, and time sir.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Cut, & whi∣sper with his Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli
SP.P: You shall find I'll forget neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You see my length.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Which I shall equall.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: So.—

LG.L: Now, Beauteous widow:—Is she gone?
I have no Courtship to pursue her with,
Nor will I offer it:—but, Let me tell you,
He that best hopes her Favour, if he have it;
He must bid fayrer for it then this sword,
And so I leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal:
SP.P: A good riddance of you

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: How is it sir?—your eye speakes trouble still.

LG.L: Sir, if it doe, 'tis onely what it has,
From your faire sisters trouble,—I must leave you
Till better houres invite me to returne,
My Love and service to you.
Nay sir Oliver,
Our wayes,—a Little way, Lye both together;
And so farre, we'll be so
I'st possible?
Be sure, you raise not this suspition si
From your owne fancie, Looke the ground be good;
The matter's weighty;—Looke it be, y'are best.
I tell you, but the voyce in Edmonton.—which is
That Mistris Margaret, is his modicum.
His sweet-meat;▪ his recreation; and the onely Instrument,
He loves to play upon.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mall:
SP.P: Indeed sir Robert?

LG.L: Whether she, like waxe
Have t'ane th' impression of his seale, or no,
I know not
That he is often at her Fathers house
That he allowes his povertie some meanes:
That he maintaines the wench, as one that sometimes
His charity, had taken to protection
I am not ignorant:—Nor has it bin
More then has gone with my Consent, and pass'd
Without suspition of the smallest sparke
Of Lust in old sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Nay I know not

LG.L: I will not to be too easie, to beleeve,
Nor yet too confident. I know there's fire
In such a wenches eye;—and old drye wood
Will soone be kindled:—If I find h be,
I'le find a way to coole him: coole'em both Exeunt
We'll all, or nothing, for half shares we Loath.

DIV2.HEAD: Act. 3.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Thrashard, with a Letter: Margaret, Gillian, and Abr'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: sir Robert's hand?—ar't sure on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am too sure,

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: And sent to thee last night?

LG.L: I, by this day, was it father▪—I know't to be his hand
What doe you thinke o' this now?

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: I know not what to thinke.

LG.L: You see the picture of a lustfull heart
Drawen to the life;—and with it, what a number
Of foule temptations, he has muster'd up,
To dim, the star-like purity of myne:
But all, no more, against my Constancie,
Then stormes of haile, against a tower;—or waves
Against a rocke, that beating are beate backe
As they begin t'assaile 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: I beleeve thee▪—yt old sir Robert.

LG.L: Yes, even old sir Robert.Enter the Lad. Mallory as a poore woman.
Who have we here? a Begger?
An she desire any thing here,
I'll desire her to be gone, with a vengeance.
Who would you speake withall?—Hum.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: A poore old woman; be not offended sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: And what would't thou have, poore old woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My busines, is to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: To me? what i'st.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I would delyver't to your self

LG.L: My selfe?
What ere it be, doe not feare to speake it,
I cannot feare to heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: What i'st woman?

LG.L: Indeed my charge is mistris, to delyver't
To your owne hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Thar.
SP.P: This is strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: —what is it?

LG.L: Though I may speake it; since you fall into
Causelesse suspitions of me—either heare me,
As I am willing to present it to you,
Or—as I am, I'll leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: Leave us?—Hoydeye—Mary come vp goody tatters▪

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Your tongue must still be running.—Heark you woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I must be Breife.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: You are very tedious me thinkes.

LG.L: Take your own course we'l leave you.—Nay, nay, come.
We shall know all anon.—thoud'st faine be scoulding.
On, or I'll set you forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Now to this private businesse: what is it?

LG.L: That happinesse that to a beauty, set
In a degree, no fayrer then your owne
Should be exceeding wellcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ha, What i'st?

LG.L: I bring you love: and to assure you 'tis
A love that's worth, the Entertaine it seekes
And fit to finde repose upon the heart
Of such a Matchlesse beauty▪ as your owne, (Caskinet)
Have brought this witnesse.—'tis a faire one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Tis—If no foule end attend it.

LG.L: come, be wise:
What my poore Artlesse toung shall fayle in, let
This never failing orator supply,
And with his golden toung, informe you, (faire one)
That he that sends it,—for the End he seekes,
Shall tender to you, whatsoe're can fall
Within the compasse, of your wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Good heaven!

LG.L: A lusty offer for that short delight
The gentleman would purchase.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: 'Tis indeed; a very bounteous offer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Take it then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You have not nam'd the sender.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: 'Tis, sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir Robert Mallory!

LG.L: That Gentleman.
I might renewe your memorie
His bountyes to your Father:—and, that bounty
Not dealt by fitts,—leaving betweene his doles,
Interims of want, and anguish; but the whole,
And totall stocke he lives on.—I might too,
Since you so much forgtt your self—
I doe not:
Indeed, I doe not; gratitude, ne'r kept,
A ruer Register of benefits
Then you may find within this bosome

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: No?—come then expresse it; mak't appeare,

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: In what?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Nay, an you mince it so.—you know my minde! He loves you faire one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Are you sure he does?

LG.L: Against so large a testimony of it,
As that you have received, and this is, (faire one)
How can you make that question?
Doe his yeares,
Equall the number, of my yeares?—does his
Estate, and mine, lye levell? weares sir Robert,
The snow-white liverie, of a single life
Vnsoild, as I doe?—can his heart, and myne,
With heavens applause be made, one heart?—partake
(As hearts, divinly brought together, doe)
One happinesse, one sorrow?—can the hand
Of any man, vnder yon golden roofe
Vntie a nuptiall gordian?—loose the knot
Has tyed the soules, of him, and his chast lady
So fast together?—make but this appeare,
And I'll beleeve thee:—I'll then say, the Heate
Hi bosome carries, is a Holy fire:
A flame, as pure a those, are sent to heav'n,
From our Religious Altars.—But till then,
Let him desist, to Roabe so foule a sinne
In so divine a garment.—Love?—'tis lust,
A sulphurous flame; which, tell him, I shall shu,
As those darke flames beneath us.
Has he this
For all the cost, that for thy Beauties sake
He has bestowed upon thee?
Helpe me goodnesse,
I thought 't had beene for heaven sake?—That some Angell
Had led his Bounty;—that it had beene done
To make his owne soule white,—and not to make
My white soule blacke, and ugly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Looke upon't;—'tis a rich prize.

LG.L: 'Tis;—yet as much too poore,
Were't ten times trebled, to effect his wish,
As Bribe an Angell to impuritie?
So beare them backe againe,—and tell thy Master,
(The lustfull Knight that sent thee) when we rate
Our chastity, above our life, we wo'not
Sel't, for such toyes as those are.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: How?—such Toyes?—are gold and jewels coun∣ted toyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Compar'd—with that rich jewell hee'd have for 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: So.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Might the exchange passe currant.

LG.L: Be advis'd;
I dare be bold to tell—you,—in this Act,
You doe not onely lose this golden offer,
With' fruitfulnesse, that you enjoy already,
'th' shine of his rich favours,—but, you sinke
Into that misery, that to the living
Is, as the Grave is to the Dead: A depth,
No beame of Fortune lookes on; for his rowne,
Deads all your happinesse.
Yet more vexation.
I will not call thee woman; for a woman
Could never labour thus, to infect the Name
With such a sinne as this is.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Beauteous Maid.

LG.L: Foule, and detested Hag, can'st breath upon me
Those golden Epithites, and with' same breath
Indeavour thus to blast it—Father, Sister,
For heav'ns sake help me:—Father, Brother, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: How now Girle?—why what's the matter?—ha?

LG.L: Examine her.
But she perchance, may tell you, what she does
Is but her duty;—'may be tell you too,
'Tis not so much her duty to the great one
That has employed her, as our love to us.
Her pitty to our poverty;—and that
To make our poore and barren fortunes fruitfull.
She comes, to water't with a golden showre. Nay, she can do it.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: A golden showre!

LG.L: O rare!—and thou canst doe that old woman,
Long maiest thou raigne, I beseech it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Thus, she may tell you father, —but, —I can tell you that she is—

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: What is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: A Bawde.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: A Bawde!

LG.L: Nay, though the brow of such a one be brasse,
Shee dares not contradict it:—shee's no lesse,
And her employment from Sir Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: How?—Come, come, take heed.

LG.L: And what should she take heed of?—an she be a Bawde,
She is a Bawde.
That's certaine,
Were her Bawdship imployed among Ladyes,
But, she shall ride in Triumph▪
Such gravitie, and such a reverend shew,
Guild such a sinne as this is?

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: A Bawd?—Now Tobacco, and Aquavitae burne thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: Now the stinking sweat upon thee, & thy painted jour∣ney-women.

LG.L: How many Noses do you think ha' bin lost
In your Bawdships service?

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: How many Coaches have you Bawdified?

LG.L: How long ha'you run on in this sin?—the Coachman wo'you,
And the horses bin whipt, for your pleasure?
was this Sir Roberts bounty?—I am poore,
And poorer must be; for his frowne commands,
All that I have to nothing,—But this sore
Shall not be cur'd with such a sinne.—Bse woman;
But wee'll reward your labour,—shall we not?

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: You lose a daughter o'me else.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: And an Abra'm o'me, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: I'll goe get n Officer; Abram, provide a Cart.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: And let me alone for a Bason.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Has Love and Bounty this reward?

LG.L: Such Love,
And such a Bounty, and the best it merrits.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: These be good Angels, I can tell you.—Looke,

LG.L: Thy Angels are all Devils;—and such gold,
But golden Fetters,—In whose powerfull tye,
Rather then I'll lie Captivated, bound
To th' hot imbraces of a lustfull man,
I'll suffer any wretchednesse.—Away,
Thou art a divell, like a woman.—
Thou—an Angell-like a Woman.
Now I have found thy goodnesse, know me better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: My ever-worthy Lady.

LG.L: Come, no more.
Thou see'st the purpose of that poore disguise.
Now beauteous Mayd, feare nothing:—thou shalt flourish,
And the more Spring, the more his angry storme
Shall beat against thee.—Here.—Nay you must take it:
That, seem'd to be the hyre of lust, shall now
Be the reward of vertue.—But, you must
Imploy't as I direct you.
But direct.—If I shall fayle in any thing enjoynd,
Let your displeasures (my worst Enemie)
Punish the fault, severely.
This is all:
Against my Husbands comming,—as I'm sure
He will not long be from thee,—I would have thee,
With this,—and more, that I'll supply thee with,
Decke up this homely Cottage;—and withall
Adde to this Beauty beauteous Trimmings, such
As beautifie Court beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How?

LG.L: Nay Margaret,
If you shall stop, at my faire purpose now,
I shall suspect your goodnesse,—'tis my pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: 'T must then be mine to serve it.

LG.L: Preethee doe,
I'll have thee brave indeed! How Brave, conceive
From these directions:—Thinke thy selfe at least,
The Heire of old Sir Robert;—nay, above it;
The Heire of one, owes greater Title;—and
To such a greatnesse suite thee.—Then—Attend me,
They are return'd already:—the Remaines—
Receive in private.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Thrashard, Gill, Abra'm, Constable, Whip and Bason.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: I have told you, what she is master Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: A Baude.

LG.L: All over,—wee'll not bate you an inch Mr. Constable,
And therefore have a care you doe justice.
I have bin among Baudes before now, and whores too:
And I thinke, I have tickled 'em soundly.
I thinke so, a Constable?
What whore dares deny him entrance?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: For what belongs to this staffe—Let me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Let me alone for the Cart.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: And me alone for the Bason.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Come, where's this same Baude here? where is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: My worthy lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: My most worthy lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: Come, wheres this baude here?—my most worthy Land-Lady!

LG.L: What have I to doe wo' Ladyes?—'tis the baude
That my authority is to cope withall.
The outside, made this vertue seeme that sinne
Lyes there that garment.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: How? that garment,

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Vertuous

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: most vertuous Lady!

LG.L: Constable, you may make a hobby-horse, o' your pain∣ted staffe, and
Ride home again. —whippe, ly thou there,
And what say you, to your bason?
I say, ti's a base one, and the barbarly knave that owes it,
They say his wife had a tooth drawen above, while he was a
Trimming belowe▪ let him keepe it for her now, an he will
For we have nothing to doe with it.
Times earnest with me, to be gone:—farewell:
You know my mynd, performe it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: With that care—I labour, my best happinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: Good Lady—well well sir Robert

LG.L: Hee's a naughty man.
I am enjoynd a taske; and to effect it,
Looke, she has given vs all this gold.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: this Gold!

LG.L: This is that golden shower I told you off:
But falls to better purpose, then, I then
Imagind, father.—how to be imployed,
Lys yet within this bosome:—but ere long,
The vertuous secret, here involv'd I'll show.
From such pure fountaines, such pure ryvers flow

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Barbara, as her Lady; Mr. William bare, Arming her in.

LG.L: Heigho! good truth this little practice of my Lady
To stand betweene her, and her foolish suitors
So to prevent their fopperies, has lull'd me
Into so sweete a fancy!—Mr. William
If all the time I have bin thus accoutred
I have not thought my selfe a very Lady,
I would I were, a very—

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Maid agen:—wouldst thou not Bab?

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Well,—an I be not, I may thanke you for it.

LG.L: What, thanke me for't and cry? come come conceal't
A little longer, and I'll warrant thee▪
Weell find thee out, a daddy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Looke you doe.

LG.L: Rash, Plush, Gregorie! what saiest thou to a Citizen?
Then thou hast 2. strings to thy bow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Two strings to my bow.—what do you mean by that roe?

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Why 2. trades Bab, two Trades.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Why what trade, have I, I pray sir?

LG.L: Why, the old trade. —thy husbands custome will get thee
Custome; and thine, thy husband, so one helps another,
And then, theres some hope of thryving.—Let me see 1. 2. 3.
After so many falls this is thy third time of rising
A great piece o' matter, i'st not?—Come, thou shalt cry,
What lack you, shew thy ware, Cu Privilegio; and
Befreind, thy freind, in a corner Enter Gregorie.
Body of me, one, of the fopps allready
Come to your state, and off.
Mr. William, hist doe you heare. I have the worst luck
At women. But I'll to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Wi.
SP.P: What Mr. Gregory!

LG.L: The very same sir.—your Ladys new gone in
May a man, be so bold, as goe see her?
Faith, not yet.
But, theres hope, you may see her anon sir,
I had a glimpse of her:—I cannot tell well
An my father, would but dy once!

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: I mary M. Gregory, his passing Bel were musick.

SP.SPEAKER: Gr.
SP.P: The man should ring it, should not sweat for nothing.

LG.L: A happe day Mr. William: and as much (though my ryvall)
To the sweete, Mr. Gregory Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Thankes, sweete, Mr. Timothy Lyning

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Howe's that sir?—lyning!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wi.
SP.P: A conceit he has, witnesse your worships cloake sir

LG.L: 'Tis lyn'd with plush indeed:
But may lyne a Ladys petty-coate,
When such a simple Gregorie as thou Dwindle.
Shall Dwindle,—but—to heare on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: The diwindle in disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Tell me of lining!

LG.L: Why Gentlemen, you come to see my Lady;
Which if you kill one another,
You'll hardly doe, beleeve me.
You have said very right, Mr. William.—
Had it not bin for that (Put up.)
You have spoke to the point Mr. William
Had it, not bin for that!—
A terrible bout, beleeve me.—
Nay I knew my hatt would part'em.
You are valiant Mr. Plush; and you Mr. Gregorie Dwindle

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Well;—an—my father, would, but by once!

LG.L: Gentlemen all,—good day.
May we not, In, to the Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: In to the Lady? —you are somewhat to rash indeed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Enter the house I meane sir▪

LG.L: She is now, goeing forth sir: —the truth is —to dinner
But here into the next street, to her brother, sir Robert Maloryes.
What fauours, she may bestow, as she passes, I know not,—
But —be not too tedious, I beseech you, —
I am to attend her thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Well, this melancholy Lady, is a hard peece o' matter to Compasse

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Somewhat, straite lac'd Mr. Rash.

LG.L: An I could but come, to vnlace her! I should make her.
Forgett, her mourning.
We all, ayme, at one marke;—
Which onely, one must hyt—I hope well▪

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: An I hope, as well, as you sir.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mr. William, Bar∣bary as before

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: And I, as well as you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Then happy man, by his dole sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Well, an my father, would but dy once!

LG.L: Have a care, you know my directions.
But, one at once, I beseech you— (Plush and Bab whisper)
Mr. Plush has the start of you Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: We cannot helpe it, worthy Mr. William.

LG.L: Hope well, and have well.—
The motto of myne Armes, if ever I lyve, to
Be Knighted—which, If, my father,—would but dy once.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: You would be a Knight in foolio.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: She shakes her head;—What does she meane by that?

LG.L: To heare him talke, so like, a humorous Coxcombe!
She has shooke him off, already.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I'll try my entertainement

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Doe▪ sir,—to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Well, I shall have my Turne, I hope anon▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: 'Twere a very ill turne, an you should not.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: No, there's the man;—see how she smiles vpon him!

LG.L: No, hres the man;—
See how shee poynts, at you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash
SP.P: She points at me indeed: but oh those smiles!

LG.L: That smiles a laugh;—
A scorne, a meere derision. Rash whispers with her; her hand after at her braest
Do you note his coming off sir.—To her, to her.
None sir, what newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu
SP.P: Nay I say nothing; —what, —it was —it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: And what say you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: What, she said,—she said.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: To please you sir, I would she had sung it.

LG.L: That clapping of her hand, upon her breast, I do not like: —
She has given Me good words; but —that's a tough bit,—
O' my stomake.
'll help you down with that; —her words, were these
It is very true; you are, a civill gentleman.
And one, above the fortunes, that you seeke:
I must protest you are sir. —but when the heart is promis'd, and the
Affctions, formerly setled, there's no calling back. —These were
Her words beleeve me▪ —
Did she not shake her head as who should say,
You are the man, must have her?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: 'Tis enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wi.
SP.P: You are must'd up in melancholy to sir—

LG.L: She gave me comfortable words; —but that embrace,
And thus, her hand, meeting her heart so oft
Moves m, a little.
Then, you'll be moved with nothing.
I'll tell you, what she said; beseech you marke me, Sir—you are
A good man; a Citizen;—Rich,—and wise—though—these three
Go seldome together;—
But,—when they doe—'tis an Aldermans pace,—
I assure you—Sometimes in a Livery gown; but—that's but—
On Festivall dayes.—The May den-head,—is your Aimes,—
In your Arms,—beleeve me, I wish one, for—my widowhood is
Otherwise promis'd.—These were her words;—
You are the man must have her—Did she smile upon you?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: that she did.

LG.L: Why, why, should you be mov'd then? Looke, he's off,
She beckons one of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Me, me, I hope, and I'll to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: You shall not go alone sir

DIV2.STAGE: Both go to her and whisper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Now, What's the happinesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: My happinesse —but, what she said; —she said.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: You have had, a long; and a very gratious hearing.

LG.L: I have I hanke her;—
A very gratious earing, Ha?— (she laughes.)
Why, does she laugh so loud? ti's not at me, I hope
At you? —at them.—laugh, at a civill Cittisen?
I could tell, what she sayes for a need sir

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I should be glad to heare it:

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Then, I will make you glad sir. —beseech you mark me▪

LG.L: You are a proper gentleman;—
Smooth, and soft,—you have not,
Your name, for nothing.—I have heard,—
You are vallian; feare no man,
But —the mn, that frights, any man, that —villaynous thing, cald-a
Sergeant, yet you have made some of them,
Run too, two or three at once
Sometimes, and glad, they ould overtake you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: This was a Ieere worth laughing at indeed

LG.L: Now for Mr. Gregory, —the country Gentleman.
(Good harmlesse thing) little or nothing to him,—
Onely tells him, his fathers old trunkes
With a codpeice; —and his breech, were not both, of a piece:
That hardly worth hal a piece; —this almost, worth halfe a peck

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: A half peck, you meane, Mr. William

LG.L: A bushell of wit beleeve me. ▪ I ha told you, what she (laughd at:)
You are the man, must have her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I hope I shall.

LG.L: Did she not point upon you thus. (making horns) — They fall off, she bec∣kons Mr. Wil∣liam, whisper.
My Lady beckons me. —your pleasure, madam.
I cannot tell; —If shaking of the head;
And serious shaking of the head, may be
A gratious figne of love; —I am the man.
O smile; —sweet smile—full of splendidious rayes;
Such,—as the Sun, at dinner time displayes—If I do not tickle her.
In figure, —Let—me be counted a Cipher.
Well,—an my father would but dye once;—
I am the man must have her.
But —ô that Hand, —her hand so white and soft,
In sweet Protests,—thus —kist her breast, so oft,
I could compose me thinkes!—the sweetest!—Well,
I am the man must have her.
Your will shall be instantly done, sweet Lady.—
Gentlemen —'tis my Ladyes pleasure, you leave her at this time:—
Nay, nay, keepe off I besecch you.—Mr. Plush,—
You are the man: —away.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Most beauteous Lady.—

LG.L: Mr. Gregory, ▪ I have sent him off, with a flea in his ear
My Lady, is your Lady,—goe.
Well,—an my father would but dye once,—then
Farewell, most Beauteous Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Mr. Rash▪ —I have given him a Box, to put his pepper in.
You are the mn shall have her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: In good deed sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: You'd heare as much from my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: O▪ ight I be so happy.

LG.L: Why, you shall sir;
I have told the Gentleman, your mind, sweet Lady,
And hee's delighted with it:—But, to heare
Your love delivered, by your owne sweet lip
would make his light heart caper.
Master Rash,
Though it scarce suit with modestie,—my blush—
Veild with this mourning habit, take your wish,
You are the man shall have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: May I build—

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: With Brick, according to the Statute sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I meane upon this promise.

LG.L: O, you meane
Upon the Lady sir: you heare you may,
The foundation is layd to your hands,
And the edifice halfe up already.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: With this, I take my leave.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Deare Master Rash.

LG.L: You'll make a rash Bargaine of this sir:
Who have we here?—Rawhead and Bloody-bones?
Good madam Bab, walke off,—what master Cutt!
