I am Cut:—but doe not you play upon my Cutt,
Lest I play upon—your pate, and cut you, as deep sir.

SP.SPEAKER: M VV.
SP.P: What me?—your friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: No matter, whether you be or no sir: Ne Hercules contra duos.

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Had you two upon you at once sir?

LG.L: An there were ten upon me at once,—
I did not desire you to helpe me.

SP.SPEAKER: M▪ W.
SP.P: I was not there to helpe thee.

LG.L: A pox o'your prating sheeps-head;—
I tell you, I did not desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Nay,—preethee Cutt be patient.

LG.L: I may chuse whether I will or no sir:—
Six,—like six o' the Constables gard,
That a man may beat with a broome-staffe,—yet
For three pnce a night they venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar. W
SP.P: What, Sir Olivers Hugh?—in hast.

LG.L: N great hast, for in hast, we run:—An we run, we may fall
An we fll, we may catch a hurt;—
An a rt will not easily be heal'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cutt.
SP.P: An you talke o' mine; y'are Coxcombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W
SP.P: Nay, I prithee Hugh say nothing.

LG.L: a man say, and say nothing?—O' nothing, comes nothing,
And he that out of nothing, can get something, does something,
More then I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Cutt.
SP.P: You doe not, Some-thing, nothing me sir: doe you?

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Nay, here's no place▪ to quarrell.

LG.L: An we quarrell, we must draw,—an we draw
We must strike; an we strike,—we shall cut; an we cut, wee
Shall bleed; an we bleed, we must to the Surgeons.
An you pte, I shall knock;—an I knock,
You must cry;—and you cry, I must kicke;—An I kicke—
I shall kicke you again sir,—
If I kicke you age,—you shall feele it;
If you feel't, ▪ you have as good as you bring;
If you have as good as you
bring, —why thn sir, I owe you nothing;
And so master Cubert have at you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Death, are you mad-men? hold, hold, hold, I say.—
Prithee put up.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: While he may put up in my belly.

LG.L: He that does so is a Coward;—He that's a coward's a rogue,
And he that's a Rogue must be whipt;—
And would I might be whipt an I doe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Give me thy hand; th'art a man▪

LG.L: He, that sayes I am not a man,—I may chance.
To make him, a boy sir.
A couple of touchy Coxcombes. But come, this signe,
Of the Hand in Hand is handsome—Gentlemen,
I have a pretty Project in my pate,
Will you assist me in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu. Cut.
SP.P: Name it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Hearke,—no more but so:—your Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: And our hearts to boote, Master VVilliam.

LG.L: Nay, there's no parting yet,—At Buttry-hatch,
In Boules,—thus deepe,—wee'll health it to the Match.

DIV2.HEAD: Act. 4.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Oliver, and the Captaine, as in the field.

LG.L: Now Knight, I see, you love a Noble promise
Too well, to Breake it:—y'are a Gentleman.
Sir, should I find, that I had lost my selfe
In any Thing, that should proclaime me lesse,
I should not hate mine enemie so much,
As such a heady Action.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: I am ready.

LG.L: I see you are: But ere our weapons meet,
Tell me, what seconds have you Captain?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Seconds?—A strange demand. —How meane you?

LG.L: Why a man,
That may assist you if you faile.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: A Second?—were any such appointed?—I have none.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: How Captaine?—None.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: I have not sir: have you?

LG.L: Beleev't, I have;—I should not else have met
So great a danger Mullynex.
A Second!
Is this the Noblenesse you Boast?—A Knight!
A servile Foot-boy, —his master ere
Give but one Copie of a noble soule
Would have disdained this cowardise—a second▪
Nay you may terme it, what you please: —no matter,
'Tis my advantage Captaine

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Ha? where is he

LG.L: You may as well demand of more, then one
For I have more, stout Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: More?

LG.L: Yes more.
To keepe, what lost can ne'r be found agen,
We cannot be too Cautelous
A man?
Insnare me thus?: where be they? If they be
As base as thou art, be they ten to one
I shall not feare the incouner.
Thinke you so sir?
A minutes patience I shall name 'em to you.
And let you see your danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Name 'em.

LG.L: Yes,
The first bold Second, that attends my Sword,
Is thine owne Rash, and inconsiderate fury;
For then that foe within a man,—without
We cannot meet that enemie, that can
Present us with more danger: There's the first,
The next my undertaking, in defence
Of such a stocke of goodnesse in that Ladŷ,
As Envy, n'er durst looke on: which who knowes not,
So faire, and just, the ever-watchfull eye,
That mid-night Actions are apparent to
Cannot but see, nor that great Ens behold,
But be assistant to't;—A third (Rash man)
The contumelious, and un▪manly darings,
That, to inforce me from the Peacefulnesse,
Ere liv'd in my calme Bosome, you have most
Uncivilly cast upon me,—Smil'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Yes.—Are these your Seconds?

LG.L: Mullinex they are.
Dar'st thou unarm'd?—Indeed a naked man▪
(For he that fights in such a Cause as thine,
With nothing in't, but an impetuous will,
Is little better—) venture all thy blood
Gainst such a great Advantage?
What I dare,
My Sword shall tell thee Bellingham.
So sudden?(Passes, Bellingham▪ onely puts by.)
You see, till now my weapon has been us'd
Meerely defensively;—To guard my selfe;
Nor point, nor edge, offring their violence
Against thy bosome.—Were I sure, I could
Put by thy furie, till it has spent it selfe,
Or tyr'd thy body past the danger of it,
The Fighting part should onely be thine owne:
Mine onely, mine owne Buckler.
Slighted?—death
I'll put your Fence-play to't a little better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: I must not dally then▪

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Come Bellingham.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Hold Captaine, hold,—you bleed.

LG.L: As you must doe,
Or all my blood's at hazard—Have I touch'd you?
You have stout Captaine,
Shall we part upon the equalitie of our hurts?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: How, part sir?

LG.L: Yes, our manhoods, standing in this equall point,
We may do't fairely; slight applyments yet
May make us whole again.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Shall a scratch part us?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: How fatall sir another close may be—we know not,

LG.L: No, nor doe we feare it: Come
Then Mullynex, what following hurts you have,
Call not the worke of my unwilling hands,
But thine own frenzie:—witnesse heav'n they are— (Fight.)
Captaine you faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Take your advantage then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Advantage sir, How meane you?

LG.L: Of my wound:
My weaknesse Bellingham,—you see there's now,
No interpos'd resistance, 'tween my heart (Throwes off his wea∣pon)
And thy bold weapon—Come.
I rather wish
That all thy blood were in thy veines againe:
Had all the fire, and livelihood it had,
Though with that strength, new courage, and the malice
That but two minutes past, pursued my life,
You should againe pursu't, and put it to
Another dangerous hazard.
Thou mai'st wish it;
For 't were no hazard, 'gainst the muniment,
And strong defences that Heaven plants about,
A soule so pure as thine is.
How? is this
The language of a wounded man, to him
That made them Mullynex?
What language fitter?
Thou art a noble enemie:—And now
My troubled understanding's calme againe,
I see my selfe worthy the wounds I have,
And all their Anguish trebled.—Thou art just.
I am to unmindfull, of what most I mind
Thy smarting faintnesse:—But, my cares shall now
Onely attend thy safetie.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Mind thine owne:—flye Bellingham.

LG.L: Let all my best desires
Be fruitlesse then.—Come Mullynex, Let me
Support thy fainting body.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Worthy sir,—y'ave a Noble second▪

LG.L: Sir I have, And whosoe're dares be a Duellist
Should have the like;
Should build his Hopes, rather upon his cause,
Then on his strength,—his skill,—and hood winck'd furie,
For these are nothing.
You have made me see▪
That Braves and Boastings in bad Causes, are
The Dolphins wanton dallying on the waves:
That sore-runs Tempests; This untimely Graves.—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter old Thrashard brave, and the Lady Mallory.

LG.L: You know my mind, faile not in any thing
That lies in my direction.
Feare not me;—you have made me brave,
And I'll doe my businesse as bravely.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: And so, for your Sonne and Daughter.

LG.L: Nay, for my Son, since he put on his Braverie,
For the part of a gallant in jeast,—He will not be perswaded,
But that hee's a gallant in earnest; Scornes to thinke o' Canvas,
Course Freeze,—or a sheep-skin Doublet;
Or to talk but of Lords, and Ladyes.—And as for my Daughters!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Your part.—

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Is a Justice of Peace:—And you are sweet Lady,—my Lady▪

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Hearke, hee's come alreadie.

LG.L: That's his hum indeed;—In good Lady,
In,—when your part comes in,
I'll give you your Qu. to enter.— Exit Lady▪ Enter Sir Robert.
An I can but hit, the state of a Justice
Handsomely. He comes, and I goe to my station.
Well Edmonton; thou that holdst her, that holds me,
In this strong meshd Net of affection, I am once again come to see thee.
How, in th' imagination of this sport,
My old heart capers?—Well? this little house,
This little Cottage, while it holds my Peg,
Is my best house,—my Castle;— Nay, my Palace,
My delicate Palace of Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: You are welcome honest Gentleman; what would you?

LG.L: Ha▪—what would you sir?
By his face old Thrashard my tenant:
But, by the reverend outside that he weares,
I know not, with what stile to salute him.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: Would you ought, with me or mine, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: I would speake with' good man of this house sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: The Right worshpfull, Master of this house, you speak to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: This house?

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: This house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: What may▪ I call your name sir?

LG.L: My name, in common, is Thrashard.—
But with the Gentile Addition, Oliver Thrashard Esquire,—
Iustice of Peace and Quorum.
Justice of Peace and Quorum.—
Doe not you know me, Master Oliver?

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: By this Chaine, not I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Not me, Master Olyver Thrashard?

LG.L: Not you,—Master▪ what shall I call thee,—Belike,
We shall know you, whether we will know you, or no sir.
Has not your worship a sonne, that men call,—
Master—Abra'm Thrashard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: May a man sir, desire to see him?

LG.L: He is not afraid to be seen sir,—Son Abram, Ent. Abram▪
Master Abra'm, come—here's a Gentleman
Desires to see you.
To see me, my Right worshipfull Father?—
An he be a Gentleman, we are to be seene, and spoke to.—
Your businesse to me sir? Hum!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Does your worship know me, Master Abraham?

LG.L: My worship does know many Gentlemen,—some Lords,
And some Ladyes too sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: But me,—your old Land-lord, Sir Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Land-lord?—to one in Sattin?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Your Worship, remembers me sure sir.

LG.L: My worship remembers you not sir: does not,—
Must not,—shall not. Land-lord, to one in Sattin!—
Did you heare him right worshipfull Father?
I heare him, my worshipfull sonne:
Just thus he talk'd to me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra
SP.P: Land-lord, to one in Sattin?

LG.L: They talke of a wonderfull yeare;—
But here's a most wonderfull Minute, worshipfull sir;—
Ha' not you a Sister, call'd Gillian?
Call'd mistris Gillian, I have;—
And you shall know that I have,
Sister, mistris Gillian, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: Now, what's the good newes wo' you now?

LG.L: there's a Gentleman,—would speake with one Gillian:
No more but so, plaine Gillian.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: You might have remembred the M. sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Which of the Ms—Madona,—Mistris, or Maukin?

LG.L: Right worshipfull Father;
Shall our greatnesse indure the Maukin?
I confesse forgetfulnesse:—your pardon, —your pardon
Sweet Mistris Gillian.
Tis well, you have chang'd your note sir▪—had you not,—
By this Chaine;—I know, what I know, I doe sir.
Did not the Civilitie of Gentilitie, stand up, as it were,
Betweene us, with-holding these two,—doe you see sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: 'Tis well sir, you doe not feele 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Doe not you know me, Mistris Gillian?

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: For, a sauie companion, I doe sir.

LG.L: Why this is admirable,
What Brokers wardrobe have they met withall,
To meet with me thus?—Let me not mistake,
And charge a kindnesse,—with unkindnesse though:
For ought I know, this may be some conceite,
That in the close, shall to my entertaine
Adde more delight and lustre.—Worthy sir,
May but my boldnesse, progresse to the sight
Of your faire Daughter Margaret I ha' done,
And rest indebted to your right worshipfull self,
With your worshipfull, Sonne, and Daughters.

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: Son Abram,—Call in thy worshipfull Sister

LG.L: Now you talke like one of us,—
A Gentle-man, a Gentle-woman
Shall talke with the gentleman, —And soe,—as the Proverbe is, tis
Merry, when Gentle folkes, meete Enter Margarett Very Braue
Sister Mistris Margaret Sister

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Your busines brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: Aske our right worshipfull father.

LG.L: I theres the starre, brighter, then Lucifer,
That ushers in my happinesse

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: With me sir?

LG.L: My beautious Margaret: how ere ot'h suddaine
changd into these rich ornaments, —I hope,
You know me, better, then your father does;
Your brother, or your sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Know you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: I hope you doe

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sooth, but I doe not sir▪

SP.SPEAKER: S. Ro.
SP.P: Not know me?

LG.L: Noe;—nor to be briefe; and plaine,
Doe I desire, to know you,
Not my Peg
Not myne owne Pegy know me?—beauteous Peg,
I am sir Robert Malory

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Now in good deed law;—in good sooth I am.

LG.L: sir Robert Mallory?-I doe not know him:
But I have heard of such a one:—a knight,
A Citty knight;—A peyce of old dry stuffe
That's good for nothing but.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Peg,-beauty, Peg.

LG.L: And yet, they say,—in his libidinous heate,
As Ranke a Letcher, —a Baboon, —a Goat

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Peg, beautious Pegy.

LG.L: A cock sparrowe;—one
As lustfull, as a Satyre! out up on him.
Wrong his good lady?—such a beauteous lady;
Nay such a vertuous lady?▪out upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Has her brave suite, made her forgett me to.

LG.L: They say, his lust most eagrely pursues
His tennants daughter: A poore Countrey wench:
A silly Girle heaven knowes;—yet wise enough,
To make the letcher lose his longing,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Ha? this the delight I▪ look'd for,

LG.L: 'Tis reported,
Ha's done her good;—settled a poore estate
Vpon her aged father;—and of goodnesse,
Must the reward be Sinne?—must she for this,
Become his whore? his strumpet?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Peg,—sweete Peg.

LG.L: Were I as she is, what so ere shee be,
I should so fit his Knight shippe; ▪ and so firke
That satyre, —Monky, —that Baboone, —that Goate—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Some Conjuration, witchcraft

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: How he sweats.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sister, pray call our mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: Lady Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: La Mal.
SP.P: How now what's the matter?

LG.L: How's this? her mother? why, this is my
Lady;▪or, —the divell in
My Ladyes likenesse.—l'me sure sheel know me.

SP.SPEAKER: La Ma.
SP.P: Desire to speake with me sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: You forsooth? —will not she know me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I cannot stand to talk sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Not with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: With you sir? —no sir; what are you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: Ha?—doe not you know me Lady?

LG.L: Know you sir?
How? —when? —where? —why? —for what sir!
How? —when? —where? —why?—for what sir? why heere's
The finest mad fitt; —the most worshipfull Peece of Lunacy, that
A man shall desire to looke on.
Why, are not you my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Thy wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro.
SP.P: My wife.

LG.L: I hope —my right worshipfull Husband —you will not
Seeme Ieerd And deryded.—
He challenges me, —for his Wife!
My Lady, your wife? By this chaine; an you play
The mad Alderman here, —you were better ha' don't in bedlam
Your wife?
Go to;—no more but so; —go to.
Our right worshippfull mother, your wife? —
By this Sattin go to; —no more but so, —go to
My mother, your wife sir? —mary come up▪ for a wife sir;
Were it not, as it is; —that Gentillity holds my hands-!
Me thinkes, in such a gentleman, as you are,
Such sport, —so old; ▪ and such a Reverend man;
This wildnesse shewes not handsome.
Handsome▪ quotha!
My wife, my spouse eny me! death they kisse:
An I be mad, —I'le play the mad mans part
A little longer —hearke you gentlewoman;
Are not you my wife? —are not you my Tennant? —
Are not you Abram Ninne? you Gillian
Of Braineford? —you pretty Peg of Edmonton?
And this Little house here, mine owne sir; —death, they Ieere me
Is your mery divell —that cheated the divell; come again to make
Merry amongst you? —well, I see, how the case stands: this is
A tricke of my Ladyes, to Racke, —to deride, —and shame me:
She has found me out▪ and there's no houlding out any longer,
Peg, —wife —Peg: —I confesse sweete Peg, there stands the Peg,
That I had a desire, to have playd at mumble de Peg with all
But —dost thou heare me? —lady ▪ madam, Peg

SP.SPEAKER: Lady-
SP.P: The old mans mad.

LG.L: I were mad indeed,—an I should not know mine own
Lady! Preethee torment me no longer, —good Love, good Hony,
Good Pigse, I was wanton; —I was wanton, —I confesse it,—
But heare what I'll tell thee, in private
When, we walke thus abroad how our once familiar
Acquaintance will Bow and Adore our Sattin. —
But, we know the worshipfull Nod; —for a word, —
We shall hardly Afford 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: May I beleeve all this?

LG.L: Beleeve it Peg? —if ere, I be troubled,
With this foolish vagary agen;
If there be, to be spied, the least touch of this, Itch about me,
Let those worthy men, with whom I sit, set me beside my seate
And devise, some new Torment, to tame me. —Nay let my frailty
Be put in Print, —and sung▪ that the City, may Ring on't!
You have protested well; and I beleeve you:
This fault, is pardoned —
You must Seale it then — kisse
How like, the right worshipfull, this now?

SP.SPEAKER: Thra.
SP.P: By this chaine, —exceeding well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Abra.
SP.P: I protest, by this sattin, it is sir.

LG.L: Please your worships,
May I possesse her now? —doe yee know me now?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Our worthy, —and right worshipfull landlord.

LG.L: Will your sattin, submit to that sir? —Peg, —I love the.
Not for thy beauty, —but thy vertues Girle.
The testimony of it, shall be this: —your states
Shall be as great, as they appeare to be,
I have spare bags, will do't wench. —Come, we must
Give Vertue now —what we decreed to lust. —

SP.SPEAKER: Mr W.
SP.P: You have done, to my directions gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Have we not, bully Will?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Have we not sir?

LG.L: I have plac'd Mr. Rash, —where he expects his lady,
With a heart, as light, as a bubble.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: And I, Mr. Timothy Plush.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu
SP.P: And I, Mr. Gregory Dwindle.

LG.L: Mine like one, that had six pence a day, for his labour,
Stands here at the upper end of Lymestreete.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: mine, in the Middle

SP.SPEAKER: Hu
SP.P: And mine, at the lower end on't.

LG.L: But all unseene, —till they see their times to discover.
Most amiable Lady, cryes mine!

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Most splendidious Beauty, mine

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Odriferous Mistris, mine.

LG.L: Proceed we now to our purpose, Away to your stands;
And stand to your tacklings tightly. (Exeunt Cut, and Hu:)
Now, must I backe, for my imagined lady; (to▪ their stands.)
Whose amiable Presence, is infinitely wisht
And expected —
Sweet Mr. William
Well, the minutes comming,
That is, as 'twere, the crowne of all the houres;
Of all the dayes▪ the weekes, of all the moneths:
Nay, in a word,—of all those many yeares
That have fore-run it.—Lady, Lady, come
Sweetest, of all sweet women, come, come quickly.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Master William & Barbary, as his Lady veild.

LG.L: Come, as you hope to be translated from a frie Cham∣ber-maid,
That is,—a Maid, & no Maid (for so are the most of your function)
To a civill Citizens wife,—Carry thy selfe,—like a woman
Of note and carriage.—That blows in jeast should swell thus!
But, this loose-bodyed blacke conceales it
Master Rash.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Rash againe, at his stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Master William.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: Sweet master Rash, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Lady,—you shoure upon my head all happinesse.

LG.L: Something she may in good time sir.—
A word in private Lady.
It would grieve a man, for one so white as she is to attend
To the middle in snow;—Nor for one so red as she, to wade to
The chin in blood:—for her white is whiter then snow, ▪ and
Her red then the blush of Roses.
It is my Ladyes pleasure, that you turn up that corner, —
And so go through Allgate to the Towre;—where—she,
Having dispatch'd a little businesse with a Gentlewoman
A little below here, will instantly be pleased to meet you,
To finish the thing you wot of.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Our happy Nuptials sir?

SP.SPEAKER: M. W.
SP.P: Your happy Nuptialls.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: The Tower?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wi.
SP.P: The Tower—Her care has made all things ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I shall attend you Lady.—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wi.
SP.P: Is not this handsome, Bab?

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: It will be anon, Mr▪ William.

LG.L: Stand fast master Plush, I beseech you,
While I goe looke out for the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wi.
SP.P: Honest Cut Hough-man!—you know your part.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: And shall act it to the life, never feare it.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil
SP.P: You are perfect too, I doubt not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: To a Syllable,—sweet Master william.

LG.L: We must not word off time thus:—Now shee's mine
Doe you stand aside, and observe us.—
So, all the state you can thinke on.
Sweet master Plush.
Honest Cut, let me be cut into steakes, if I make not thee
A great man, for this piece of service.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: I know you a man, of a most magnanimous soule sir.

LG.L: Thou fair'st the Sun ere darted ray upon;
Thou Non-parallel,—thou jem, thou Paragon,
What shall I call thee?—Call thee what I can,
I shall but praise thee,—like a mortall man,
Thou more then mortall woman!—O, me thinkes,
I could so tickle thee in phrase and flash,
Beauty was ne'r so tickled! Let me embrace thee.—So!
And kisse thee,—so!—Nectar, Nectar▪ Nectar.
He said he would Tickle her, but she has tickled him,
I am sure on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Depart so soone, sweet beauty?

LG.L: You know my heart, and have it: —I have businesse,—
But here hard by sir, for an houre, or so;
Which done I shall returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: But will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Will I?—what else doe you thinke I came for?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Queene of beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: And then.—

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: And then,—I shall attend you Lady!

LG.L: But to your stand, —you must be private, —so sir, Exit Plush to his stand.
How thinke you of this Master William?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Wil.
SP.P: O, rarely, rarely!

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Then Sculke a little longer, and we'll have it rarer yet sir.

LG.L: Stand fast master Dwindle, I beseech you. Enter Hugh at his stand.
Whilst I goe looke out for the Lady
Cut?—And how ist, Madona Barbara?—She is now
My charge—Goe,—backe to the stand, you came from, tell
Spruce master Plush, that the Lady is now at her businesse; and
That you'l bear him company, til her Laiships time of returning.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Tou hast counselled me right rarely.—

LG.L: So,—as your lesson is;
With all the Pride a womans heart can thinke on —Mr. Dwindle▪
Honest Hugh, —well, Enter Greg Dwindle, from his stand.
I shall thinke upon thee.
Thinke?—Can you thinke me, a new suit?—
Thinke me a new Sword? —Thinke me a new Belt?—
Thinke me a new Beaver▪?—or think me a Pouch full of pieces▪
I thinke,—you thinke,—no such matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I thinke thou thinkst right honest Hughkin.

LG.L: Why then,—I thinke what I thinke,▪and
There's an end of our thinking.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Well, an my Father would but dye once.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Your Father dye?

LG.L: Hee's threescore yeares old and upward,
Is't not time he should now, goe downward?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: And time, that you should goe Westward.

LG.L: How I love you Lady,—you may see by my eyes:—
Which have nothing else to do, were the day as long as a dozen,
But to gaze up n thee,—and thy Beauty,
O- by my heart,—sweet Lady.—By that lip I doe—
By those two lips;▪which I take for a Book,—with two leaves—
And thus—I take,—my oath upon it.
But hearke you,—doe you heare?—master Dwindle.
'Slight, there's an oath indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I sweare but seldome,▪but then I doe sweare to purpose.

LG.L: I see,—you like her;▪ that liking her, you love her;—
And that loving her, you will lye with her,▪and that lying with
H you will—

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Wht sir.

LG.L: What sir,—an you know not what sir, you may turne
over to me sir: An lye with her, and doe not something;
Wh th let her say, I have—Nothing.
B gone sweet Lady? Why I thought you had come▪
To goe to Church with me to be married.
You know my heart, and have it: onely sir,
I have a little businesse, —here hard by;
An houre, or such a thing;▪ which overpast,—I shall Returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: But will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: By this kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: A most sweet oath, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Betake you to your Stand then, and stand close.

LG.L: Being so neere the place I am to goe to,
Till I returne, pray keepe him company.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gr.
SP.P: Wel, an my Father would but dye once.▪

LG.L: Mistris Barbary, I could praise thee a whole day together,
But, we must follow, what followes.—
Me thinkes— Enter Plush and Cut, from their stand.
This houre, is a very long houre, Master Cutbert,
A lovers houre, in the presence of his Mistris, is a minute▪—
But, in her absence,—he thinkes every minute an houre sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Well, shee is a wondrous sweet one.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: You doe not smell her hither, I hope sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: I meane in her Aspect;—her countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: How blest shall you be in this Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: I thanke the Fates▪ I shall:▪ & thou shalt not be unthought of.

LG.L: I doubt not your worships bounty.—
Beseech you a word in private.—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Hugh and Gregory from their stand.

LG.L: You are the most impatient Lover, that beautifull eye ever
Look'd on, why halfe her houre is not out yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Well,—'tis the longest houre.

LG.L: But, as you were about to say,
Concerning the choyce of a wife sir.
Why, thus I do say, honest Hughkin,-I would have my wife,—
Like Alexanders—Horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: How's that?—Your wife like a Horse sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Like Alexanders horse, I would sir.

LG.L: And why,—like Alexanders Horse Master Gregory?
Why, as that Horse,—would let no man ride him, but Alexander?
So, I would have my wife, let no man ride her, but- Gregory.
Good truth, you say right;—In right there's no wrong;▪
No wrong, there's no hurt;—no hurt, there's no danger,—
No feare,—and▪ no feare,—why so much for that sir.
Birlady, as you say, she stayes somewhat long indeed sir.—
Pray heaven, your Rivall- Master Gregory Dwindle have not
Met with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Dwindle?

LG.L: He,—I do halfe suspect it—He has been later with her▪
Then you imagine, he has sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: The next time I meet him,—I will kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: I would not have you die sir:—But—

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: That Butt, will I Run full Butt at, and broach him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: I doe but tell you, what I thinke, Master Gregorie.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: That Plush has met her?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: I have seene somewhat more then I'll speake of.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Well,—an my Father would but dye once.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: I talke sir of Plush, your Rivall;—you must fight.

LG.L: Well, an I must, I must;—I'll examine my Sword,
And see, how hee'll stand to the Businesse.
Your Rivall sir, your Rivall,—
With his Sword starke naked already▪

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: My Sword can goe naked too sir.

LG.L: Your Ryvall sir,—turne, and defend your selfe;
Y'are a dead man else.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Dwindle, thou hast wrong'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Plush,—thou hast wrong'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Thou hast stolne away my Lady from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Thou hast stolne away my Lady from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: For which▪—though I be loth—

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: For which, though I be loth—

LG.L: Pox o'you both, for Coxcombs.—
As Y'are a Gentleman, strike him.
As y'are a Gentleman strike him. While they are fight∣ing a farre off.
An they hurt one another;—hang me.
Hold, hold, hold, Enter Rash, Barbary, Mr. William and a Priest.
You are gul'd Gentlemen, you are guld:
Looke there's the Lady you fight for.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Mr. Rash the Mercer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: And the Parson, that Ioin'd together.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Revenge, revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Blood, and Revenge, assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Parson.
SP.P: Why gentlemen?—what meane you, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Mr. Plush,- Mr. Gregory Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Mr. Dwindle; Mr. Timothy Plush.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: This-Lady, is for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Your Beauty Lady.

LG.L: Lady, me no Ladyes; for I'll be a Lady no Longer, I am,
My Ladyes Chamber-mayd; doe you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu. Greg.
SP.P: My Ladyes Chamber mayde?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: An you know her not yet, you may know her hereafter,—by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: By that sir?—what sir? Villany, Villany, Villany!

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Noe matter for that; I'll be honest enough to you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Villany, villany, villany▪

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: You cannot fly so fast; but I can follow—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: I'll-follow too, —and use▪ my best skill to Attone'em▪

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: My Ladyes Chamber-mayde?

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: The Lady her self, is a dish,—for your selfe, to feast on.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: I'st possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: As to doe thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: O rare.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Gull him with the maid,—to help me to the bed of the Mistris?

LG.L: You see my Love sir.—foolish Remnant Seller;
A Citizen:—you are a Gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Well; an my Father, would but dye once!

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: That time, will come.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I would it were gone, honest Hughkin.

LG.L: So much, I know my Ladyes Bosome sir.
That what I speake, I'll Iustifie.—Shee's yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: I thinke, I have said enough sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I shall have her.

LG.L: Shall I talke?—shall I walke? shall I eate? shall I drinke?
Shall I sleepe?—shall I live?—shall I dye sir?
But, you must tread the path, I put you in;
An you straye, but a foote, you loose her.
But,—as I have told you, Mr. Gregory Dwindle,
You must not misse a halfe of my directions.
Honest Cut,—I am for this thing,—any thing,—all things,
To compasse the Bed of the Lady.
An I do not do as I should do▪ —may I never come to doe,—
What I woo'd doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: You have said enough:—And go I'le direct you better.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Do this, shee's yours:—As we go Ile direct you better.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. 5.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Captaine in his Night-gowne, Doctor, Servants, Chaire and stooles.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Have tender hands upon him. —so, now Leave us.

LG.L: Your goodnesse mixing with those thing you apply,
Doubles their vertue, and to all you do
Sets a most wisht Conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: See who knockes.—

LG.L: I make no question, I shall find you such▪
Concerning the concealement of my friend,
That worthy Gentleman, Sir Olyver,
As I desire, to find you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: All I am,—is at your service, Captaine.—Now sir.

LG.L: Sir, here's the mourning Lady so much talk'd of▪
Sir Robert Mallory, and his Lady sir,
That good, good Lady.
Trust me, y're to blame.
They were not entred with you?—Preethee step
And do't with thy best dutie:—Nay, I knew
The Rumour of our unsuspected Quarrell
So spread, as I have caus'd it to be spread,
They would not long be from me, Enter Sir Robert Mallory, hi Lady, & the Lady Mosely.
They are come,—you know my thoughts.
Feare not my care; I doe sir,
Ladyes,—and kind Sir Robert,—you are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: I'st well, to see men Ill sir; —How I'st Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Faith a weake man Sir Robert.

LG.L: Nay, nay sister;
Then I shall chide you, weeping? Come come drye
Thou hast wept too much, allready.
Had I thought
To come, had bin to meete this new occasion
Of greife, and anguish, I must tell you plainely
You had come alone, for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Come, wipe your eyes.

LG.L: You may as well forbid the Bigswoln Cloude
By the Suns Ardor melted into Dropps,
To fall upon the Bosome of the earth;
As my swolne griefe (Resolved into these teares)
To fall from their full Fountaines. —Half the Number,
Is for thy wounds (rash Captaine) t'other Halfe,
For that sad gentleman, (where ere he be)
Whose hard happe 'twas to make 'em: And, in them,
To make me Author of this Bloody worke
And his perpetuall Exile
'twas my phrensie,
I, wretched I, was Author.
Interchange
Embraces, congyes; —and, to our Beleefe,
The Language of two Brothers; —And all this
But meerely shew? —false colours, —a faire Masque
Ore the stern; —Rough, and Formidable Face
Of such a Mortall Envy? —you were cunning
But, to our purpose sir:—our comming was,
Hearing that worthy Gentleman, Sir Olyver▪
Vpon this Bloudy Accident, was fled.
(For nothing else, is on the 'voyce of Rumour)
To learne, the certainety of you.
Hee, fled.
To stoppe his flight, (though for his safeties sake
He hid himselfe in some obscure disguise)
I gave him, what incouragement, I could;
Told him, my wounds were nothing: made their depth
Appeare, but shallow scratches; —That the losse.
Of twice the Blood went from 'em, could not leave
My heart so Pale, as to Recoile against
The worst they threatned: —Have proclaimed the hand
Of Noble Bellingham from all this Blood,
As white as Innocency.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: How?

LG.L: I have,
And tane the purple staine upon my self;
For 'twas my selfe wounded my selfe; —not He.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Your self?

LG.L: You call me, to a strict account.
For he that's lost in such a storme of furie,
Cannot be said, to be himselfe.
You have spoke
A noble way to acquit him.
But, it may be
Imagining, we know the Place to which
He has betane him to conceale himself,
You speake all this, in hope wee'll name the place,
And so Discover him, to what revenge
Your spleene shall seeke upon him.
To revenge?
To any, but your self this harsh Suspition
Should have as harsh an answer: But to you
I'll thus acquit me: doe you see this Ring?
Your Teares, will hardly let you see't: —yet Lady
Pray looke upon it. —Can▪ you call to minde
A former sight on't?

SP.SPEAKER: La Mos.
SP.P: I have seene it sure.—Sir Olyver, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Lady 'twas.

LG.L: Now I looke better on't, it was indeed.
Thou knowest it too.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: I doe sir: —what of this?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: What comfort yeilds the sight on't?

LG.L: I have shewne
This, to acquit me of those treacherous thought
That you suspected in me, 'gainst the life
Of noble Bellingham;—Who—as he parted,
(To take a Journey in uncertaine paths,)
Left this Ring with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: You have charm'd us now,—from all our harsh suspitions.

LG.L: Till he gave me
This cause to hate him, I ne'r lov'd him: Now,
I doe not grieve so much, this losse of Blood,
Nor all the smart goes with it, as by this
I have lost the sight and the society
Of such a faire example of all Goodnesse,
As I shall ne'r more looke on.—I could tell you
How much (beyond the suffrings of a Man)
I dar'd him to the field:—How meeting there,
He did not looke upon me as a Foe;
Or, one that thirsted a Revenge,—but one
That onely met to shew he durst,—and then,
Seem'd—in the language of his looke—at once
To speake the Dreyrie issue of a fight,
And—to advise to shun it.—Till he saw
My weapon out,—His slept within his Scabberd.
Both equally prepar'd,—my weapon onely
Labour'd for blood;—His, onely his owne guard
Without desire to touch me. In a word,
What you see done,—I made him doe;—and done,
His heart wept blood to thinke on't.—When another
(Seeing his state thus dangerous) would have fled;
I could not counsell him to't,—but in this,
As all his Actions, valuing noble things
Above his life—he tooke into's embraces
My wounded body;—Brought me from the field;
And to the diligence, and well known skill
Of thi good man has left me: Leaving with him,
(I almost blush, to doe him right in that)
His ample satisfaction for my Cure,
Or whatsoe're may be demanded.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Sir ya've given him a fair Character,

LG.L: He were
Baser then Envy would not. —and all this
He did i'th Honour of your Beauty Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: deare sister.—

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: He lov'd you dearely: Can his Praises▪ then offend your eare?

LG.L: No every sillable
Of his commends is musique. —But to thinke,
That, for my sake this much Commended worth,
(Yet much above, the great commends it has)
Should- thus be lost O, I could weepe my self,
Into my sencelesse Statue! —Bellingham!
O Noble, noble Bellingham!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Sister.

LG.L: Lady:
If his Commends be musicke in your eare,
Be patient, and heare more on't. —once agen.
To this:—'Twas his; —and (as I said before)
He left it as he parted: But, not myne,
But thine, —thou best of women:—his desire,
You'd weare it for him:—when, you looke upon it,
You'd thinke upon him; thinking, that you'd give
His wandring stepps fair wishes.
As I would
My soule, departing, on her Iourny hence
To her eternall dwelling.
Pray observe,
How in this ring, h'as emblem'd all the world,
And all her painted gloryes. —looke you Madam▪
A bed of Roses-wither'd. —And the word,
Caelestia non sic! —tis not thus in heav'n!
There's no decay; no failing, All things there
Their Innate Beautyes doe for ever weare:
For ever, their full flourish:—Here below,
Our best Ioyes wither; All things Ebb and Flow. —Indeed—
He was not master of that thing, from which
He did not draw, (as out of this small compasse,
Sweete and Celestiall uses!—was a man,
As heaven had onely made a man to make
By his example, multitudes of men,
Such as it selfe would have 'em. —you weepe still.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: No hope, agen, to see him?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Doe you wish it?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: As life, as health, as Heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You will not then deny one kindnesse to me?

LG.L: what i'st Captaine?
Now you have left your love-suite sir; —and seeme
To be a spoakes-man, for young Bellingham
She can deny you nothing:—what i'st Captaine?
Faith onely this Sir Robert. —I would Begg
Since Shee desires to see him, that, for that
Shee'd Let me weare this Diamond but till I find
Fit time to send it to him.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Send it?

LG.L: Yes—No strict enquiries of me: I have spoak
If you dare trust me—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: But direct me sir—I'll Bear't my selfe.

LG.L: You know my Bosome Lady;
If you will send it.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Take it Captaine,—but—

LG.L: I conceive all that you can urge me to,
And will performe to your owne wish.—My wounds
Call for your helpe sir.—I must now desire
You would be pleas'd to leave me.
Wee'd be loth
To be a hindrance to the happinesse
That we all wish for.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Farewell noble Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Come, shal I look upon your wounds?

LG.L: No, no:
I fain'd my selfe much fainter then I am,
To hasten them to leave me.
Thankes to your Art; —and you great Master of it.
I feele my legs sturdy supporters now, Ent. Bellingham from the Arras.
And for a need could travell.—Bellingham.
You have observ'd these passages?
I have;
Unseene I have seene, and overheard 'em.
Then—I hope you have seen, that I have plaied the part
Of a just Advocate.
Sir, y'ave done
For me,—the most unworthy—such a Love
As I shall ne'r make even with.
No more;
Th' Exchange is made, Sir Olyver:—there, —take it, (the Ring)
She dreames not sir, you ha't so suddenly:
But, what's to follow—I must change my seat,
For this has tyr'd me sir.—Wee'll take more houres
Sufficiently to thinke on.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oly.
SP.P: Noble Captaine.—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Master William, Cut, and Hugh.

LG.L: Will these foolish Suitors be troublesome still?
And still live in hope of my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Hang 'em Puttocks; you shall heare more of them hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: But how is't with Rash, and his piece of Rash, Mistris Barbary?

LG.L: Faith, he's not so rash as he was, with some supple perswasions
Of mine;—her hanging the head,—beating the breast, wringing
The hands,—wiping the neyes, —and lamentably breathing some
Hundred and fifty Heigh'os; he was wonne in the end to busse her, to
Embrace her,—to busse her again.—He buss'd, —and she buss'd, —and they
Both buss'd so long, —till at last,—overcome in this conflict of kisses;
He yeelded himselfe her Captive, and has vowed
Till his death to love her as deare as his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: How now? what Musick's this?

DIV2.STAGE: Musicke, and a Song from the musick roome.

LG.L: 'Tis applied to my Ladyes melancholie,
But I feare me to little purpose,—peace, a Song.

DIV2.STAGE: The Song ended, Enter Sir Robert.

LG.L: Now, Master William,
How fares my Sister, and your Lady?—ha?
Shee's a sad Lady;—and so sad, Sir Robert,
That no delights, that her most loving friends
Present unto her Sences, from her breast
Can take one minutes anguish.
Well, I feare me,
Shee'll pine her selfe into her winding-sheet.
Now Peg, how is't?—how does our sister? ha?
Can'st smile, and tell me, there's as cleare a skie
Vpon her beauty? No, that down-cast looke
I feare me's her sad picture.
'Tis indeed:
But the occasion of her grieving's chang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: What's the sad matter now then?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Onely now,—young Bellingham's sad absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Bellingham?

LG.L: For which, with many sighes, with many teares,
Many abrupted sillables, extolling
His noble worth and goodnesse;—she accuses
Her wretched selfe;—making her selfe the cause
Of that sad fight, and this lamented Issue.
It grieves me thus to see her;—and as much
To leave her in it,—I must in again:
Come, will you in, Sir Robert?
Goe, I'll follow.
Heav'n never pity me, but for the weight Capt. Enter Mullynex and Sir Oliver as the Doctor.
Of sorrow, lyes upon her tender heart,
My heart's as full of anguish.
My brave Captaine,
Doe you so much compassionate the teares
Of my poore sister, as thus weake and ill,
To come to see, and comfort her?
Sir Robert,
I thanke my great Restorer, I am well:
But, were I at the weak'st, hearing her griefe,
I should forget mine owne, and tender that
My best respects, and service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: You are Noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Still grieving her lost Husband?

LG.L: Questionlesse,
There's some remaines of that:—but with it sir,
Sh'as now th'addition of your blood: with that
The flight of him, that yours commends,—and his
Better considered worthinesse, has made
So noble to her, Noble Bellingham,
For whom, as one by her occasion lost,
Her conscience seemes to check her:—and retyr'd
Into her melancholy chamber, sits
As in a Cell:—whence all the loving meanes
That can be us'd, have not the power to move her.
In her Chamber?
And this strong Passion for young Bellingham?
Pray call a servant.
Some within there. Enter a Servant.
Beare this to your sad Lady sir, and tell her
The man she grieves for, will not long be from her;
And that the bringer of it does desire
She would be pleas'd, that he might see her here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Here, tell her here:—goe, fetch her.

LG.L: Nay, if that
Be her disease, this is the cure or nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Why, is young Bellingham return'd?

LG.L: You see
The Ring she sent him is return'd: from that,
Let me alone to cure her.
Now my Peg,
What comfort brings thy comming?
That my tongue
Were furnisht with those words that might delight you:
I know, there's in this wish, and the sad signes
It is delivered with, answer enough
Touching your worthy Sisters heavinesse,
To make your hearts as heavy.—But my charge,
Is from my Lady, to intreat you would
Be pleas'd to come and see her.
See her wench?
Prethee goe in againe, and tell thy Lady,
We hope she'll leave her solitary Cell,—and come to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: To you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Nay, nay, goe,—and tell her what I bid thee.

LG.L: Pray sir Robert,
What Beautie's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: A pretty beauty sir.

LG.L: But that her wearings are so faire and costly,
I should—from Fames rich pencilling a Virgin,
That was your foster daughter, take that piece,
And this to be one beautie.
So to take,
Is not to take amisse sir; this is she:
This is that Girle, beleeve me.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Still a Virgin!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: As from her Mother, Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: And her heart—her own sir, and unpromis'd.

LG.L: Yet beleeve me,
Dost like her, noble Captaine?
To enjoy her,
As the sole mistris of my purest desires,
Is the greatest happinesse that I can aime at.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: You know her Birth.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: 'Tis noble in her vertues.

LG.L: If vertue be the best Nobility,
'Tis so indeed.—Goe, thou shalt have her Captaine.
And howsoere, set lightly by, till now,
Sh'as now some weight;—five hundred Pieces Captain,
Five hundred golden Pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Your Lady Sister's comming sir.

LG.L: Please you,
I'll in, and try my fortunes with her sir.
What follows of the Ring I sent,—this Doctor
Can as well finish, as my selfe were here,
I'll not be long about it.
Say you so sir?
Here, take this Ring, 'twill helpe you.—Never not feare her:
Goe in and wooe her; win her, and then weare her, Exit Capt.
I see that Ring has brought her:Ent. Lady Mosely, La. Mallory, and Mr. William.
How is't Sister?
Reviv'd a little by the sight of this,
But let me see the man I sent it to,
And then that cure upon my griefe,—you wish'd▪
Is to your wish effected.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Master Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Where is he?—speake, who brought it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: I did Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: You?—What are you sir?

LG.L: My Profession Lady,
My habit shewes you: I am he that cur'd
The Captaine that he wounded.

SP.SPEAKER: Ladies.
SP.P: Mullynex?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: That Captaine Ladyes.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Is he well?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: He is.

LG.L: As meat can make him; and his flesh as whole as a fish,
Take my word for that Lady sister.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Ha?—where? where is he?

LG.L: Faith, somewhere here about the house he is,
And see, he appeares in his likenesse. Enter Captaine with Margaret.
Y'are as good as your word;—you have got her.
Not with child yet, but I hope I shall doe-ere long:
Now heaven give us joy, and all's done sir.
Heaven give you joy;—I'll give you the gold I promis'd you.
You see the Captaine is well Sister.
Why then returnes not Bellingham?—or does he,
(Hearing his goodnesse has inthrald my heart)
Neglect me now, 'cause I neglected him,
When my fresh griefes inforst me?—If he doe,
I must confesse it but a just revenge:
And so (as long as griefe shall give me leave)
Shall patiently indure it.
But you shall not,
You have indur'd beyond a womans strength,
And shall indure no longer.—Master Doctor,
You are the man must cure her.
Beauteous Lady,
'Twas your command, I should not trouble you
With any tedious Love-suit;—and you see
I have done, what you have enjoyn'd me:—Now I hope
I have your voluntary grant.
I am now,
What Noble Bellingham shall please to make me.
No doubt he'll make much o'thee Sister,—wilt thou not Knight?
My brave sir, of a thousand per Annum?
Shee's now mine owne; and in this union sir,
The best delights that her desires would have,
Are mine, mine owne;—and I shall so pursue 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: And what say you master Captaine?

LG.L: To my Pegge▪
I say (as he has said)—that shee's my selfe,
As you have said;—that shee's my Girle;—my Pearle;
Her voyce, I will hang in my eare:—Her face in mine eye;
Her pretty little waste in mine armes;
And being in armes, let the Souldier alone to come on sir.
Why god mercy Captain.—Now to Church, Enter master William.
Nay, wee'le not lose a minute.
Beseech you stay a little, there's that mirth in your way Enter Rash and Bab like a Puritan.
I dare promise will be worth your beholding:
See, see't appeares.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Who's this?—Master Rash?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: The very same, an't please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Your suit continued still sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I have turn'd up another suit now sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Your Wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: Even so sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Verily so sir.—Doe not you know me Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: Truth not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Nor you, nor you, nor you?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: We know thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: What art thou?

LG.L: This 'tis, to put off our vaine & superfluous colours, and to walk
As becommeth the zealously metamorphos'd. I was your
Creature Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mos.
SP.P: How? my creature?

LG.L: In the phrase of the world 'twas so. —But I am now,—mine own,
Yet,—verily —I doe erre,—for —no wife, —is her owne disposer.
Verily none:—for we —to affirme sincerely, are but members
Of our Head, the man; —our Spouse, —and our Superiour.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: How Bab!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: That Barbary Button, beleeve me.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: How comes she to speake in the nose so?

LG.L: The tone of the Brethren, and the Sisters;
But, what doe you thinke of this Member?
Though begot,—and conceiv'd in vanity:—being borne in the
State of Matrimony, the offence,—may no doubt be remitted, and the
Innocent, in time, may prove a most,—zealous member.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: And what thinke you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I thinke, as my wife thinkes,—for man and wife are one.

SP.SPEAKER: Bab.
SP.P: Verily, you have said, & said- like a zealous husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Give way there Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter?

LG.L: Your shadow Lady;—and your Rivall sir:
The prettiest fancie; the most dainty Dreame!
Beseech you Madam, stand aside a little, Enter Plush and Gil∣lian as the Lady.
Much joy betide your worship.
Godamercy;
Having this Beauty, I have all the joyes
My Auspicious Starres could give me. Honest Cut;
This service shall not be unthought of Cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Well Master Gregorie,—an you doe hang your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Why, an he does, he does,—we cannot helpe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: Yet it would grieve a man.—

LG.L: Grieve a pudding: —And it grieve not him to do't, it shall never
Grieve me to heare on't.—We are now man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: For better, for worse sir.

LG.L: Then, for better, for worse, I will keepe her.—
Why, there's another Rivall o'mine,—Sir Oliver,—
Say he should take the same journey, and goe to
Heaven in a Halter after him; can I helpe it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: I confesse, you cannot:—thanke you master Plush.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: I did but say,—an —an you should sir.

LG.L: No, though the losse be somewhat grievous to me▪
The sorrow shall not goe so deepe:—she's yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: As sure as the Church can make her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: What must be, must be sir; —much joy betide you.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Gre∣gorie, the old Gentlewoman, as the Lady and Hugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Thanke you.

LG.L: Now Lady,
In spight of all my Rivalls, you are mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Gent.
SP.P: I am sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I know thou art, and thereupon—.

LG.L: Not a kisse, till you come to your Chamber,—then
Shee's your owne all over.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: 'Tis enough: Now, an my father would but dye once.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: When Plush shall heare of this,—hee'll hang himselfe.

LG.L: An he do—to make a wry mouth at the match,
I cannot helpe it; I should not doe so by him though.—
Save you gentlemen. We have the Lady Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: We have the Lady-gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: Is my Sister divided betweene you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: You cannot both have the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Alas poore Gregorie!

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Alas poore Plush!

LG.L: Alas poore coxcombs! here's a coyle indeed
About a worthlesse shadow:—What am I sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ro. Capt.
SP.P: Alas poore Plush!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal. Wi.
SP.P: Alas poore Gregorie!

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Why, who have I then?

LG.L: Why, who doe you thinke you have sir?—
This is no Ivy bush, nor I an Owle.—
D'yee stare upon me? say?

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: Are yo' my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Gill.
SP.P: I cannot tell,—how doe you thinke sir? ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oli.
SP.P: Having got this Beauty from you, we got this Beauty for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cut.
SP.P: You'll thinke upon me I hope sir.

LG.L: The Gentlewoman is my Sister; —I tell you no more but so sir:
Shee loves no large protests:—Embrace and kisse,
And 'tis sufficient.—There's an end of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rob.
SP.P: And what say you sir?

LG.L: Why, I say—I —know not, —what to say,
Shee—is not —very old sir —is she?
In her Hood, —some—50—But in some Dressings she has,
Shee may passe for a thing of twenty.
Here be some Gutters;—Channels,—and Long lanes,
But being fill'd up,—with —a little Plaster of Paris —

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: The Face, —may passe—

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: For a Paris-garden face:—it may sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Gent.
SP.P: Come, ne'r be melancholy,—you shall find a woman of me I warrant you.

LG.L: Thou speak'st, —like a good old woman.—Well —
An my wife would but dy once.

SP.SPEAKER: Old gent.
SP.P: How Sweet-heart? —your Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I know what I said, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old gent.
SP.P: Nay, pree thee sweet-heart kisse me: —faith you shall —

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: There—Puh! Well, —an —my wife would but dye once!

LG.L: Come, you are so melancholie:
Why here's a man suffers, as much as you;
Or you master Plush,—and yet you see hee's patient.
I thought I had married a Lady too, —but —by lady,
There's no such matter.—We must be contented now though.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Well—here be three of us.

LG.L: There be indeed;
Stand together, I beseech you, and be silent.
Come, let's to Church:—nay, wee'll not lose a minute▪
Brother;—Sonne,
So, now I'll call thee Captaine; having got
The inestimable Jewell, treasur'd up
In this rich Cabinet: —for such a Jemme,
Is the deare heart of Peg my Girle;—my Pearle;
This beauteous, vertuous, Country Girle:—And such
The Prize your fortune, —or, your goodnesse rather,
Has drawne in this sweet Beauty.—Many joyes,
Heav'n send you both.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Mal.
SP.P: Many sweet Girles and Boyes.

LG.L: Why, godamercy my old Pegg,—Away. Flrish. Exeunt Rash, Plush, Gregorie, and their Wenches staying, Mr. William enters to them.
In love, and warre, no danger to delay.
COme, will you goe Gentlemen?—
Nay you must be with us,
And ghests at this Wedding dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Must we?

LG.L: By any meanes in the world sir.—
Their Cates will not rellish without you.
A word or two first, to ease our stomackes here, and our▪
Stomacks shall be there in an instant.—Gentlemen,
You see how we have bin abus'd,—Basely abus'd and gull'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I, with this —crackt Commoditie.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: I, with this—old Commoditie.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: And I,—with this—scoulding Commoditie.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: How this cracke,—

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: How this face—

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: How this tongue—

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: May be soulder'd,—

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: May be vernish'd,—

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: May be charm'd.—

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I,—any man can, let him tell us—no;—no man?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Not one word of comfort.

LG.L: If not, for us, so cunningly betraied
To these hard bargaines;—for our Country Maide.
Our vertuous City Dame, be pleas'd to shew▪
That you are pleas'd,—
Though we be hardly so,
These tricks thus put upon's.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: And then, this—Cracke.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: This—wither'd Face—here.

SP.SPEAKER: Plu.
SP.P: and my Gillians clacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.P: I Solder'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Greg.
SP.P: Vernisht.

SP.SPEAKER: Plush.
SP.P: Charm'd.

LG.L: Here you may please
To understand, that what's set downe, for these
Is spoke for All: that by this part we meane,
All the whole Bulke, and Body of the Scoene
We have Presented: —which—or Ebbes, or Flowes,
Or stands, or falls,—withers, or sweetly growes
From the Aspects you give it:—Let them be,
But gracious, we are yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: And wee.

SP.SPEAKER: Women.
SP.P: And wee.

LIST.ITEM:
Abraham Thrash-hard—his Sonne.
Servingmen.
Cutburt
Hugh
